questions.text: A male infant delivered at 39 weeks via vaginal delivery is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for microcephaly and a rash. The pregnancy was uncomplicated. There was no use of recreational substances by the mother and no exposure to pets. Membranes ruptured spontaneously 6 hours prior to delivery, and delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at one and five minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 67/38 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Weight is at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile, body length is at the 10<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is at the 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. On physical examination, there is a generalized blueish petechial rash on the face and extremities. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Fundoscopic exam reveals chorioretinitis. Brain imaging shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for Zika virus
Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the blood

questions.solution:
This newborn is small for gestational age and presents with microcephaly, a purplish-blue rash (“blueberry muffin rash”), and chorioretinitis. Brain imaging shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection (CMV) is the most likely diagnosis. Positive urine or salivary polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for CMV is diagnostic for congenital CMV.

Congenital CMV is the most common congenital infection. It can be acquired through vertical transmission in utero, but infection can also be acquired at the time of birth. Maternal history may reveal a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy, and the neonatal history often reveals that the infant is premature or small for gestational age, as in this case. Newborns are usually asymptomatic at birth, though they may develop seizures and developmental delay later. Physical exam findings may reveal a purplish-blue (“blueberry muffin”) rash and microcephaly, and fundoscopy may show chorioretinitis and retinal hemorrhage. Sensorineural hearing loss is commonly detected on hearing screens.

A complete blood count, urine or salivary PCR, and possible viral cultures from blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) should be obtained when congenital CMV is suspected. Typical laboratory abnormalities include elevated liver transaminase levels, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and thrombocytopenia. Positive PCR testing or cultures with brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings of periventricular calcifications or cysts and ventriculomegaly will confirm the diagnosis of congenital CMV infection.
   
Head ultrasound parenchymal calcifications with congenital CMV infections. Reproduced from: Statdx

Option Analysis

✅ Cytomegalovirus (CMV) urine polymerase chase reaction (PCR):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for Zika virus:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is used to confirm congenital Zika virus infections, which typically present in newborns with microcephaly, hypertonia, clubfoot, and macular scarring or chorioretinal atrophy on fundoscopic exam. However, the findings in this patient are more consistent with congenital CMV infection.
❌ Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the blood:
Incorrect: RPR is used to diagnose syphilis, which can cause a desquamating rash on the palms and soles, hepatomegaly, and skeletal abnormalities in congenital cases. However, this infant's findings of microcephaly, chorioretinitis, and periventricular calcifications on brain imaging are more consistent with congenital CMV infection.
❌ Rubella IgM titer:
Incorrect: Rubella IgM titer can confirm the diagnosis of congenital rubella infection, which typically presents in newborns with a heart murmur, rash, and cataracts. This patient’s presentation is instead consistent with congenital CMV infection, which can be confirmed by urine PCR.
❌ Viral culture of the mouth:
Incorrect: Viral culture of the mouth is commonly used to confirm congenital herpes simplex virus infection. This patient’s presentation is consistent with congenital CMV infection, which can be confirmed with urine PCR.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician's office for evaluation of abnormal movements and atypical frequent episodes of crying. Parent reports that the patient has had intermittent “jerky” movements of the upper extremities over the past 2-3 days. Parent also notes intermittent facial twitching as well as grimacing. The “crying spells” occur randomly and are not brought on by preceding incidents. These episodes are unusual for this child, whose parents describe her as typically happy. The patient has no significant past medical history, though she did have upper respiratory infections in the winter. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 107/71mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.  Physical examination demonstrates evidence of abrupt nonrhythmic movements of the upper left extremity. Erratic movements of the facial muscles and intermittent grimacing are also noted. Palpable nodules are present on the volar aspect of the bilateral wrists. Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are positive. Which of the following parts of the physical examination is most likely to be abnormal given the likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient can be diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever, based on the findings of Sydenham chorea. She also has a fever, and subcutaneous nodules. Close examination of the joints is most likely to reveal findings associated with joint involvement, including polyarthritis with joint effusions, warmth, swelling, and pain with range of motion. Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints is the most common clinical finding associated with acute rheumatic fever, found in 60-80% of cases.        

A focused history and physical examination are critical for making the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. Symptoms typically present 2-4 weeks after a strep infection. The most common symptom is migratory polyarthritis affecting the large joints. In addition, patients may present with fever, findings of carditis, small subcutaneous nodules found over the extensor surfaces, and the characteristic rash (erythema marginatum). Rarely, patients may present with a clinical condition called Sydenham chorea, which is characterized by unilateral choreiform movements that resolve with sleep. Patients with Sydenham chorea can also exhibit tic-like features, facial grimacing, and mood disturbances. Formal diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is based on the Jones criteria.  

Option Analysis

✅ Joint examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Otic examination:
Incorrect: Examination of the ears is unlikely to reveal any further abnormal processes. Otitis media/externa and other auditory issues are not associated with acute rheumatic fever. Joint findings such as arthritis, with pain and swelling are much more likely to be found. 
❌ Pulmonary examination:
Incorrect: There are no pulmonary conditions associated with acute rheumatic fever. Joint findings such as arthritis, with pain and swelling are much more likely to be found. 
❌ Oropharyngeal examination:
Incorrect: While acute rheumatic fever typically develops following strep pharyngitis, it is a late sequela following the initial infection and does not present until weeks after the pharyngeal phase of infection. Chorea can develop anywhere from one to eight months after a Group A streptococcus (GAS) infection. Therefore, examination of the posterior pharynx is likely to be normal. 
❌ Ocular examination:
Incorrect: Ocular examination is unlikely to reveal any significant abnormalities associated with acute rheumatic fever. Joint findings such as arthritis, with pain and swelling are much more likely to be found.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to fever, vomiting, and confusion that developed over the course of a day. Three days prior, she fell off her bike while going down a hill and suffered multiple abrasions to her left knee that were cleaned and covered at home. The patient has no significant past medical history and is up to date on her vaccinations. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 132/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 86/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient responds only to painful stimuli. The skin over the left knee shows signs of swelling and erythema but no necrosis or bullae. A diffuse erythematous, macular rash with desquamation is noted over her trunk and extremities, and shedding is significant over the palms and soles. Laboratory studies are obtained and can be seen below. Blood cultures are collected and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     12 g/dL    
 Creatinine     2.0 mg/dL    
 Leukocyte count     15,000/mm3

choices.text: Administer intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Await blood culture results before starting antibiotics
Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with close follow-up
Surgical debridement of the knee wounds

questions.solution:
This patient with a prior history of skin wounds presents with the sudden onset of fever and a desquamating rash with involvement of the palms and soles. She has hypotension with multiorgan involvement and altered mental status. The most likely diagnosis is toxic shock syndrome, which should be treated immediately with intravenous fluids and broad spectrum empiric antibiotics.       

TSS is primarily caused by toxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep). It can occur as a complication of invasive GAS disease with skin infections being a common source for severe infection. The toxins lead to an overwhelming inflammatory response, which leads to multiorgan failure.       

Patients with TSS typically present with sudden onset of high fever, hypotension, and multiorgan involvement. A characteristic diffuse erythematous, macular rash with subsequent desquamation, especially on the palms and soles, is often observed. Laboratory findings in TSS may include elevated liver enzymes, elevated creatinine levels indicating renal involvement, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. When toxic shock syndrome occurs as a complication of invasive GAS infection, diagnosis is established via positive culture for GAS (typically blood or wound cultures in patients with skin infections).       

The cornerstone of treatment for TSS involves the administration of intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum empiric antibiotics. Antibiotics should include clindamycin or linezolid because of their antitoxin effects. An example of an appropriate antibiotic regimen is vancomycin plus clindamycin plus a carbapenem.   

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Await blood culture results before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Waiting for blood culture results will delay necessary treatment for this patient with toxic shock syndrome and will likely result in serious morbidity or mortality. This patient with hypotension and shock needs intravenous fluids, broad spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and supportive care. 
❌ Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with close follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and laboratory values suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS). TSS is a rapidly progressive and fatal condition without prompt treatment. Discharge home would be inappropriate. This patient with hypotension and shock needs intravenous fluids, broad spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and supportive care. 
❌ Surgical debridement of the knee wounds:
Incorrect:  Early surgical debridement should be performed if there is evidence of necrotizing soft tissue infection, which this patient does not have. This patient with hypotension and shock should be treated immediately with intravenous fluids, broad spectrum antibiotics, and supportive care.   
❌ Administer intravenous immunoglobulin:
Incorrect: Intravenous immunoglobulin may be considered as adjunctive therapy in patients with TSS. This patient with hypotension and shock should be treated immediately with intravenous fluids, broad spectrum antibiotics, and supportive care.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 24-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for new-onset fever over the last 24 hours. Parents report that the prior evening the patient was experiencing poor feeding and lethargy. He normally wakes every 3 hours to feed, but last night he slept for a 7-hour interval. The patient has a 2-year-old brother who is in daycare. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the infant appears fussy but consolable. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory results are shown below. The culture results are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Complete blood count (CBC)    
 Hemoglobin     13.9 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     40.9%    
 Leukocyte count     21,200/mm3    
 Platelet count     370,000/mm3    
 Neutrophils     45%    
 Eosinophils     3%    
 Basophils     0%    
 Lymphocytes     46%    
 Monocytes     7%    
 Urinalysis         
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative    
 Nitrite     Negative    
 pH     6.8        
 Protein     Negative    
 Blood     Negative    
 Specific gravity     1.010    
 Ketones     Negative    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Bilirubin     Negative    
 Inflammatory markers    
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     7 mg/dL    
 Procalcitonin (PCT)     1.1 ng/mL
questions.solution:
This 24-day-old boy has a fever without an obvious source. Lab work shows leukocytosis, abnormal inflammatory markers,and a normal urinalysis. The current recommendation for patients who are 22-28 days old with a fever and abnormal inflammatory markers is to perform a lumbar puncture to obtain cerebrospinal (CSF) studies and to start empiric antibiotics.        

The initial work-up for infants 0-60 days old who present with a fever includes obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), inflammatory markers such as c-reactive protein (CRP) and procalcitonin (PCT), blood cultures, and urinalysis.        

Infants less than 21 days old also need a urine culture and lumbar puncture for CSF studies. If the infant is at increased risk for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, such as when there is a maternal history of genital HSV lesions or the infant presents with seizures or vesicles, they should also be tested for HSV.        

Additional evaluation of infants 22-60 days old with fever depends on the results of the urinalysis and inflammatory markers. If inflammatory markers are abnormal, CSF studies (and a urine culture if the urinalysis was abnormal) should be obtained in infants 22-28 days old and considered in infants 29-60 days old. If inflammatory markers are normal but the urinalysis is abnormal, a urine culture should be obtained. If both the inflammatory markers and urinalysis are normal, CSF studies should be considered in infants 22-28 days old but are not necessary in infants 29-60 days old.        

The initial evaluation for infants with fevers is performed to diagnose bacteremia, urinary tract infections, and meningitis/encephalitis. Depending on the infant’s symptoms, additional evaluation with viral panels, chest x-ray, or stool culture may be obtained.   

Option Analysis

✅ Perform a lumbar puncture:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain a respiratory viral panel:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers and no obvious source of infection should undergo a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. Once this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a respiratory viral panel can be obtained if clinically appropriate. 
❌ Obtain a stool culture:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers require a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. After this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a stool culture should be obtained if clinically appropriate. 
❌ Perform a drug screen:
Incorrect: Although this patient appears fussy and lethargic, the fever makes an infection more likely. The next step in evaluating a febrile infant between 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers is to perform a lumbar puncture. 
❌ Obtain a chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-60 days old with elevated inflammatory markers, require a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. After this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a chest x-ray should be obtained if clinically appropriate.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old female infant delivered at 39 weeks via vaginal delivery is evaluated for jaundice and profuse nasal discharge in the pediatrician’s office. The mother had no prenatal care. Rupture of membranes occurred 12 hours before delivery, and delivery was uncomplicated. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 127/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 73/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Weight is 2500 g, and body length is 50 cm. On physical examination, the patient has a moderate amount of mucopurulent nasal discharge. Eye exam is within normal limits. The patient appears jaundiced and has generalized lymphadenopathy. Abdominal exam reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Congenital infection is suspected. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be expected?

 Laboratory values      Results     
 Hemoglobin      13 g/dL    
 White blood cells     37,560 /μL    
 Platelets      90,000 /μL    
 Total bilirubin      15 mg/dL    
 Direct bilirubin      0.5 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Congenital syphilis by Norman Cole. Licensed as public domain from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Public Health Image Library (PHIL). Reproduced from Wikipedia. 

This infant, born to a mother who had no prenatal care, presents with mucopurulent nasal discharge, jaundice, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results show leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia. This patient most likely has congenital syphilis. A desquamating rash on the palms, soles, or diaper area is characteristic of congenital syphilis.

Congenital syphilis is caused by vertical transmission of Treponema pallidum from infected mothers. Maternal history may reveal limited prenatal care or a genital chancre. Newborn exam is typically normal at birth, but by 1 to 2 months of age, infants typically develop a desquamative maculopapular rash (often seen on the palms, soles, or diaper area) and snuffles (rhinitis with mucopurulent nasal discharge). Other common findings include pseudoparalysis due to bone inflammation resulting in severe pain during movement, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and condyloma lata (wart-like lesions on moist areas of skin). Late congenital syphilis presents after two years of age with oral findings like Hutchinson teeth and mulberry molars. Affected children can also develop deafness, interstitial keratitis, and skeletal abnormalities, such as saber shins.

With these physical examination findings, syphilis should be suspected. Complete blood count (CBC) may show thrombocytopenia and anemia. Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL) or rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of the infant and blood of the mother should be obtained to make a diagnosis. Intravenous penicillin is the treatment of choice.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Cataracts:
Incorrect: Cataracts are commonly seen in patients with congenital rubella, along with a heart murmur and a purplish-blue rash caused by dermal hematopoiesis (also referred to as a “blueberry muffin” rash), which are not noted in this patient. Congenital syphilis is more likely in this case, and the classic skin finding is a desquamated rash on the palms, soles, or diaper area.
✅ Desquamated rash:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heart murmur:
Incorrect: Heart murmurs are commonly seen in patients with congenital rubella. These patients may also present with cataracts and a purplish-blue rash caused by dermal hematopoiesis (“blueberry muffin” rash), which are not noted in this patient.
❌ Microcephaly:
Incorrect: Microcephaly is seen in patients with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV), toxoplasmosis, or Zika virus infections. The findings in this patient are more consistent with congenital syphilis.
❌ Vesicular rash:
Incorrect: A vesicular rash is typically seen in patients with congenital varicella zoster (VCZ) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. The findings in this patient are more consistent with congenital syphilis.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a fall at a nursing home. The patient was trying to get out of bed when he lost balance and fell to the floor. He subsequently experienced severe pain in the right lower extremity. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and Alzheimer disease. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the right leg appears shortened and externally rotated when compared to the left. He is able to move the right toes and sensation is intact in the right lower extremity. After further evaluation, the patient is scheduled for surgical correction of a right femoral neck fracture. Preoperative administration of which of the following antibiotics would be most appropriate in reducing the risk of postoperative infection?
questions.solution:
This patient is scheduled for surgical correction of a femoral neck fracture. He should receive preoperative prophylaxis with cefazolin to reduce the risk of postsurgical Staphylococcus aureus infection.

Cefazolin, along with cephalexin, belongs to the 1st generation cephalosporins. These medications provide coverage against Gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus viridans, Streptococcus pyogenes, methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus), Proteus mirabilis, Eschereria coli, and Klebsiella pneumoniae.

Indications include surgical prophylaxis as well as treatment of urinary tract infections and minor skin and soft tissue infections (eg, cellulitis, soft tissue abscess).  

Option Analysis

✅ Cefazolin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin is used for chemoprophylaxis in individuals who have had close contact with patients diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. However, it is not effective against Gram-positive cocci and is therefore not typically used for preoperative prophylaxis.  
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Prophylactic amoxicillin can be administered to patients at high risk for endocarditis (e.g., valvular disease, prosthetic valves) prior to undergoing surgical or dental procedures. In contrast, this patient lacks such risk factors.  
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Although chloramphenicol has activity against Gram-positive organisms, its use is limited by its toxicity profile. Instead, cefazolin is a more appropriate agent for preoperative prophylaxis.  
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be used to provide prophylaxis against travelers diarrhea, Pneumocystis jiroveci, and Toxoplasma gondii. However, it is not routinely used for preoperative prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for management of septic shock due to pneumonia. The patient has hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. The patient is currently intubated and sedated with a central venous catheter and arterial line in place. Current ICU medications include norepinephrine, piperacillin-tazobactam, propofol, and vancomycin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/82 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On auscultation of the lungs, there are minimal rhonchi compared to the day of admission. Laboratory results are detailed below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Switch antibiotics to ceftriaxone and azithromycin

questions.solution:
This patient was admitted for septic shock and is currently hemodynamic stable on broad spectrum antibiotics. The patient has Streptococcus pneumoniae isolated on sputum culture analysis. Once a culprit organism is identified, patients should receive targeted antibiotic therapy with de-escalation of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Diagnostic evaluation of patients with sepsis includes investigations to search for a source of infection. Generally, patients with sepsis should have blood cultures, potentially sputum cultures, urinalysis and potentially urine cultures, and chest radiography. In addition, patients should have labs obtained, including CBC, CMP, lactate, arterial blood gas, and possibly also procalcitonin level.

If no source of infection is identified during the initial work-up, patients should have imaging obtained, including CT of the brain, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. In addition, patients should be considered for lumbar puncture for evaluation of meningitis.

Septic patients may have leukocytosis and an elevated procalcitonin level, which is an inflammatory marker more specific to bacterial infection. Culture results should be followed and analyzed to evaluate for a causative organism and for antibiotic susceptibilities. Once a clear source has been identified, patients should receive tailored antibiotic therapy and de-escalation of broad-spectrum antibiotics to mitigate the risk of antibiotic resistance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Switch antibiotics to ceftriaxone and azithromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continue current management:
Incorrect: This patient has a confirmed source of infection with identification of the organism and should receive targeted antibiotic therapy. Continued administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics once a specific organism is identified is inappropriate. Additionally this patient may be weaned off the norepinephrine at this time.  
❌ Add vasopressin:
Incorrect: This patient has a stable hemodynamic status; administration of additional vasoactive agents would be inappropriate. At this point the patient should be weaned off norepinephrine.  
❌ Perform a lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is an invasive procedure that can diagnose underlying meningitis. This patient has evidence of pneumococcal pneumonia as the likely source of sepsis; lumbar puncture is invasive and unnecessary.  
❌ Add itraconazole:
Incorrect: This patient has cultures positive for a specific bacteria and no evidence of fungal organisms. Adding an antifungal medication is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is admitted to the burn unit for wound care and skin grafting of a 25% total body surface burn. Past medical history is unremarkable. A central venous catheter is placed in the subclavian vein for administering medications, and a nasogastric tube is inserted for enteral feeding. On day four of hospitalization, the patient develops fever and tachycardia. Temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 104/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness and erythema at the site of central line insertion site. Chest radiograph shows no abnormalities. Blood cultures are drawn and empiric antibiotics are started. Which of the following factors most likely increased the patient’s risk for developing this condition?

choices.text: Length of time the catheter has been in place

questions.solution:
This patient with a burn injury, fever, and tachycardia in the presence of a central venous catheter that has been in place over 2 days with signs of infection at the insertion site most likely has a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). This is further supported by the absence of signs and symptoms indicating another source of an infection.

CLABSI is a primary bloodstream infection that develops at least 48 hours after central line placement or within a day of central line removal. It is typically caused by Gram-positive bacteria that migrate extraluminally from the normal skin flora, although Gram-negative bacteria or fungi can also be responsible depending on several host- and catheter-related factors. It usually presents with signs and symptoms of systemic infection (e.g. fever, chills, fatigue) and possibly shock in the absence of findings indicating another source of infection. Physical examination may show signs of catheter insertion site infection (e.g. local erythema, tenderness, purulence).

The duration of catheterization is one of the main risk factors of CLABSI development with an increasing risk with longer duration of catheterization. Other risk factors can be divided into host-related factors (e.g. parenteral feeding, immunodeficiency, loss of skin integrity, malnutrition) and catheter-related factors (e.g. catheter location, poor infection control during insertion, catheter site care).  

Option Analysis

✅ Length of time the catheter has been in place:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type of feeding:
Incorrect: Although parenteral feeding (TPN) significantly increases the risk of CLABSI, this patient is being fed enterally via an NG tube, which is not associated with an increased risk of CLABSI.  
❌ Patient age:
Incorrect: Extremes of age are associated with an increased risk of CLABSI. This patient’s age is not a predisposing risk factor.  
❌ Location of catheter placement:
Incorrect: This patient has a central venous catheter inserted in the subclavian vein which, compared to other locations (such as femoral and internal jugular vein), is less likely to be associated with CLABSI.  
❌ Length of hospitalization:
Incorrect: Although the risk of CLABSI increases with the length of hospitalization, this patient developed signs of infection relatively early in the hospitalization (day 4). Therefore, this is not a major risk factor for the development of CLABSI in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath that started thirty minutes ago. The patient has COPD and small cell lung cancer, and he does not wear oxygen at home. While vital signs are being obtained, the patient suddenly becomes lethargic and starts gasping for air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals absent breath sounds in the right upper and middle lung zones. Which of the following additional findings would be seen in the case of tension pneumothorax?

choices.text: An apical bleb on chest radiograph
Tracheal deviation towards the side with decreased breath sounds

questions.solution:
Pneumothorax describes air in the pleural space around the lung. If this air continues to expand, it can build up significant intrathoracic pressure and start pushing on mediastinal structures. This can cause tracheal deviation away from the pneumothorax. This can also cause significant pressure on the heart, impairing filling and ejection leading to hypotension. Tension pneumothorax is a type of obstructive shock. It can be diagnosed clinically when there is resultant hypotension in a patient with known/suspected pneumothorax. It is a clinical diagnosis that does not require imaging and can be diagnosed when there is respiratory distress, tracheal deviation away from the side of the pneumothorax, decreased or absent breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax, and distended neck veins and hypotension from increased central venous pressure. When it is recognized, emergent needle decompression should be performed.

Other causes of obstructive shock include pulmonary embolism (diagnosed via CT angiography of the chest or V/Q scan) and cardiac tamponade, which is diagnosed clinically but supported by RA/RV collapse on transthoracic echocardiogram.

Blood cultures, urinalysis, and imaging can help diagnose septic shock. Response to intramuscular or subcutaneous epinephrine and an elevated tryptase can help diagnose anaphylactic shock. Brain or spinal cord imaging can confirm CNS injury and support a diagnosis of neurogenic shock.

Laboratory findings in hypovolemic shock may show severe anemia in hemorrhagic shock or signs of volume depletion (e.g. elevated BUN and creatinine) and hemoconcentration (elevated hemoglobin) in non-hemorrhagic shock.

Elevated troponin and ischemic changes on electrocardiogram are used to diagnose myocardial infarction. BNP and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can help diagnose severe heart failure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypotension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pleural lung sliding on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Absent pleural lung sliding is seen on ultrasound in the case of pneumothorax since air in the pleural space prevents contact and “sliding” of the visceral and parietal pleura.  
❌ An apical bleb on chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A pulmonary bleb is a small collection of air between the lung tissue and pleura. When a bleb ruptures the air escapes into the chest cavity causing a pneumothorax. When blebs become large and come together they are called bulla. Unless blebs ruptures leading to a pneumothorax, or form very large bulla, they are usually asymptomatic.  
❌ Tracheal deviation towards the side with decreased breath sounds:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax causes significantly increased intrathoracic pressure and will push the trachea away from the pneumothorax. The trachea deviates toward the pathologic lung as described only if there is significant volume loss in the lung (e.g. lobe resection, severe mucus plug/atelectasis).  
❌ Flattened neck veins:
Incorrect: With pneumothorax increased central venous pressure causes distended neck veins and hypotension.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for 1 month of shortness of breath and abdominal distention. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, morbid obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient takes losartan for his hypertension but does not always take it consistently, and he does not use his continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 144/95 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the lungs are clear upon auscultation. The abdomen is nontender to palpation. There is a fluid wave and dullness to percussion. There is bilateral lower extremity edema. Serum white blood cell count and creatinine are normal. Paracentesis is performed, which shows a serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) of 1.5. Which of the following findings would likely confirm the cause of this patient’s ascites?

choices.text: Right atrial pressure measurement on echocardiogram

questions.solution:
Ascites (excessive or abnormal free fluid in the peritoneal cavity) usually occurs due to intra-abdominal pathologies, but it is also associated with many different systemic disease processes. Clinical history, physical examination, and serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can help determine the underlying etiology of the ascites. This patient with dyspnea, abdominal distension, and a SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL likely has ascites secondary to right-sided heart failure. Hypertension, morbid obesity, and untreated sleep apnea can lead to pulmonary hypertension, which eventually causes right ventricular failure. Elevated right atrial pressures on echocardiogram indicates pulmonary hypertension.
 

Careful history and physical examination can give clues to the cause of ascites. History should focus on chronicity and progression of the ascites. Slowly progressive ascites usually suggests more chronic etiologies, such as cirrhosis, peritoneal malignancy, nephrotic syndrome, or right-sided heart failure. Acute onset ascites usually suggest more acute etiologies, such as portal vein thrombosis, acute pancreatitis, or acute liver failure. Assessing for symptoms of volume overload (e.g. dyspnea, lower extremity swelling) and abdominal pain is important. It is also important to inquire about coexisting diseases, such as malignancy as well as kidney, liver, or heart disease.

On physical examination, patients should be assessed for signs of volume overload. Patients with cirrhosis or nephrotic syndrome will generally have systemic volume overload, whereas patients with ascites from acute pancreatitis or portal vein thrombosis generally do not. Patients with cirrhosis may have stigmata of cirrhosis. Significant abdominal tenderness to palpation may be seen in acute pancreatitis, acute liver failure, and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Right atrial pressure measurement on echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urine protein/creatinine ratio:
Incorrect: Urine protein/creatinine ratio can be used to diagnose nephrotic syndrome if it is >3 (or >3.5 per some definitions). However, nephrotic syndrome is not the likely cause of this patient’s ascites given the SAAG of 1.5 and normal serum creatinine.  
❌ Amylase level in ascites fluid:
Incorrect: An elevated amylase level in ascites fluid would be seen in ascites due to pancreatitis. This patient’s history is largely inconsistent with pancreatitis, and the condition is usually associated with an SAAG <1.1 which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ Cytology from ascites fluid:
Incorrect: Malignant cells found on cytology from ascites fluid would indicate peritoneal carcinomatosis. Patients often have weight changes (weight gain from significant ascites or weight loss from cancer-related cachexia) and may have leukocytosis. More importantly, ascites associated with peritoneal carcinomatosis would be associated with an SAAG <1.1 which is not present in this patient.  
❌ Alpha-1-antitrypsin level in stool:
Incorrect: An elevated alpha-1-antitrypsin level in the stool would be seen with protein-losing enteropathy. This patient has no diarrhea or steatorrhea. Moreover, protein-losing enteropathy is associated with an SAAG <1.1.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to weight gain and constipation. She has no significant past medical history and does not drink alcohol or use tobacco products. The patient has gained 5 kg (11 lbs) in the last month and feels very bloated. She has also experienced mild lower abdominal pain. The patient was previously having daily bowel movements and is now only having two bowel movements per week. There is no associated hematochezia, melena, rectal pain, or tenesmus. Past medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen is distended and a fluid wave is present. There is mild abdominal tenderness to palpation diffusely. Paracentesis is performed and shows a serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) of 0.8. Which of the following tests will most likely provide this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ascites can occur from intra-abdominal diseases or systemic diseases. The clinical history and physical examination can often tease out the cause. However, paracentesis with ascites fluid analysis provides additional information and is sometimes required to make a diagnosis.

The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to distinguish between portal hypertension-related causes and other causes of ascites. It is calculated by subtracting ascites albumin concentration from serum albumin concentration.

SAAG ≥1.1 indicates that there is mostly fluid (and not much protein) “leaking out” into the ascites and indicates portal hypertension-related causes. In contrast, a SAAG <1.1 implies there is much more albumin “leaking out” into the ascites fluid and is somewhat analogous to exudative pleural effusions (i.e. infection and malignancy are high on the differential diagnosis). SAAG <1.1 indicates causes not related to portal hypertension, such as peritoneal carcinomatosis which is likely in this case, nephrotic syndrome, and secondary (not spontaneous) bacterial peritonitis (e.g. peritoneal dialysis catheter infection).

If an ascites fluid cell count shows ≥250 PMN/mm3, this finding is diagnostic of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Elevated ascites fluid amylase may indicate acute pancreatitis. Ascites fluid cytology may diagnose peritoneal carcinomatosis.

This patient’s presentation is concerning for malignancy, possibly ovarian cancer, which is challenging to detect early. Patients may actually present with weight gain and increased abdominal girth (rather than weight loss) due to significant accumulation of ascites.  

Option Analysis

❌ Serum lipase:
Incorrect: Elevated serum lipase and epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back are diagnostic of acute pancreatitis with or without CT imaging findings. This patient’s history is largely inconsistent with the presentation of acute pancreatitis.  
✅ Ascites fluid cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver biopsy:
Incorrect: This procedure would be appropriate to diagnose cirrhosis or infiltrative liver diseases. This patient’s history could be consistent with cirrhosis, however, the SAAG <1.1 makes this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This test would be appropriate in patients with suspected heart failure. The lack of dyspnea and the SAAG <1.1 makes heart failure an unlikely cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Ascites fluid cell count:
Incorrect: Neutrophils (PMN) ≥250 cells/mm3 in ascites fluid is diagnostic of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. However, this patient is afebrile, and she is experiencing minimal abdominal pain. These findings make spontaneous bacterial peritonitis unlikely.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the intensive care unit on the fourth day of hospitalization. The patient was admitted with an upper gastrointestinal bleed which led to hemorrhagic shock. A urinary catheter and internal jugular vein central venous catheter were both placed on admission. The patient was transfused with three units of packed red blood cells and underwent upper endoscopy with endoscopic treatment of a bleeding gastric ulcer. Hemoglobin has been stable since then. Today the patient’s temperature is 38.7 ºC (101.7 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 99/58 mmHg, respirations are 14/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. The skin around the central venous catheter is erythematous. Blood cultures are obtained and Staphylococcus aureus grows out of 2 bottles. Urinalysis shows 3-5 white blood cells/hpf and is negative for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who has been hospitalized for several days has developed a new fever. While there are many causes for fever (e.g., malignancy, vasculitis, venous thromboembolism), all hospitalized or recently hospitalized patients who develop a new fever should be promptly evaluated for a nosocomial (healthcare-associated) infection. Many types of nosocomial infections exist and management differs depending upon the underlying infection. The main types of nosocomial infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), surgical site infection (SSI), hospital- or ventilator-associated pneumonia (HAP or VAP), and healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).
 

This patient has both an indwelling urinary catheter and a central venous catheter, putting him at risk for both CAUTI and CLABSI. Erythema around the central line, along with the finding of S. aureus bacteremia, is concerning for CLABSI. Patients with CLABSI will often have purulent drainage from the central line site as well. This patient has no urinary symptoms, no urinary leukocyte esterase or nitrites and only a small amount of pyuria, so CAUTI is unlikely. In addition, S. aureus is not usually a urinary pathogen, so if it were to be found in the urine culture, then this would indicate bacteremia rather than UTI. Given the S. aureus bacteremia, this patient’s central line should be removed, and he should be started on empiric IV antibiotics that cover S. aureus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Remove the central venous catheter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Remove the urinary catheter:
Incorrect: While this patient does have pyuria (WBC in the urine), it is not significant pyuria with only 3-5 white blood cells/hpf. Additionally, nitrites and leukocyte esterase are not present, and the patient has no symptoms to suggest a urinary tract infection. S. aureus is generally not a urinary pathogen, so if it is seen in the urine, it often indicates bacteremia.  
❌ Administer oral vancomycin:
Incorrect: Oral vancomycin is used to treat C. difficile colitis. It is not absorbed systemically, and therefore it is not used to treat other types of infection. It would not be used to treat this patient who has a central line-associated bloodstream infection.  
❌ Administer IV ampicillin plus gentamicin:
Incorrect: While this antibiotic combination could treat S. aureus, it is unnecessarily broad for an identified organism, and there is a significant risk of side effects with gentamicin. Empiric treatment with IV vancomycin would be appropriate to cover for potential MRSA, with a change to nafcillin if the organism is methicillin-sensitive. Regardless of the antibiotic regimen chosen, the central venous catheter should be removed.  
❌ Repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: Both blood culture bottles are positive and no intervention has been done yet (e.g., removing an indwelling catheter, starting antibiotics) so there is no reason to repeat cultures at this time. After treatment is started blood cultures can be repeated to ensure clearance of bacteremia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is seen on the seventh day of hospitalization. He was hospitalized because of a perforated gastric ulcer that required surgical repair. The patient has been mostly bed-bound since the surgery and has been slow to recover. Today the patient has had five watery bowel movements. Temperature is 38.4 ºC (101.1 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 125/76 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has dry mucous membranes. There is moderate tenderness to palpation in both lower quadrants of the abdomen. Serum white blood cell count is 18.4/mm<sup>3</sup>. Urinalysis shows 3-5 white blood cells/hpf and no leukocyte esterase, nitrites, or blood. Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Inadequate offloading of skin pressure points

questions.solution:
This patient who has been hospitalized for several days has developed leukocytosis and a new fever. Hospitalized patients who develop a new fever should be promptly evaluated for a nosocomial (healthcare-associated) infection. The main types of nosocomial infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), surgical site infection (SSI), hospital- or ventilator-associated pneumonia (HAP or VAP), and healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).

This patient with a perforated gastric ulcer likely received empiric antibiotics, which significantly increase the risk of healthcare-associated C. difficile infection (CDI). Patients with CDI generally present with watery diarrhea and associated abdominal symptoms (e.g., bloating, nausea, abdominal pain, and tenderness). Watery diarrhea usually occurs several times per day.

History and physical examination can often be used to determine the likely source of a nosocomial infection. Patients with a CLABSI or SSI will often have pain, erythema, fluctuance, and purulent drainage at the central line or surgical site, respectively. Bacteremia from CLABSI may cause significant fever, chills, and rigors. Patients with CAUTI may have suprapubic discomfort/tenderness and dysuria. Patients with HAP or VAP will typically have shortness of breath, increased sputum production, and decreased breath sounds in the lung fields affected by the pneumonia. Patients with VAP may also have sputum production in the endotracheal tube and changes in their mechanical ventilation requirements.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Presence of indwelling urinary catheter:
Incorrect: This can predispose patients to catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI). However this patient does not have suprapubic tenderness, and there is only mild pyuria on urinalysis.  
❌ Presence of central venous catheter:
Incorrect: This can predispose patients to central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs). Patients with CLABSIs often have high fevers and rigors with the presence of a central venous catheter with local signs of infection (e.g., erythema, purulent drainage) around the insertion site. They do not typically have watery diarrhea.  
❌ Inadequate use of incentive spirometer:
Incorrect: Appropriate use of incentive spirometry is very important in hospitalized patients, especially after surgery (particularly intra abdominal surgery). It can help prevent pneumonia and atelectasis. This patient’s presentation is not consistent with hospital-acquired pneumonia or atelectasis.  
❌ Inadequate offloading of skin pressure points:
Incorrect: Bed-bound patients are prone to developing pressure ulcers and subsequent skin and soft tissue infections (SSTI) on the skin at bony prominences. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).

questions.text:
An 84-year-old man presents to the emergency department from a nursing facility after a fall. Paramedics report that the nursing home staff reported that the patient has been more fatigued over the past 24 hours. The patient cannot provide a history due to baseline mental status from Alzheimer dementia which the nursing home staff reported as unchanged. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, Alzheimer dementia, and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 82/65 mmHg, pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam the patient is fatigued and ill-appearing. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids, piperacillin-tazobactam, and vancomycin; and bloodwork (including blood cultures) is obtained. Results of the initial work-up are detailed below. A central venous catheter is placed and norepinephrine is started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
The initial work-up and management of a patient with sepsis includes measuring lactic acid and drawing blood cultures as well as administering broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV hydration. Following initial management of hemodynamic instability, patients should undergo a thorough evaluation to determine the source of infection, which would include a thorough skin examination in this nursing home patient with Alzheimer dementia who recently had a fall.

Sepsis refers to an exaggerated immune response to infection associated with end organ dysfunction and potential shock. The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal and may originate from any tissue, which initiates a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms.

Patients with sepsis typically present with tachycardia, fever, and often hypotension as well as associated symptoms secondary to the source of underlying infection. However, patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms, including fatigue, dizziness, or syncope, or, as in this case, they may be unable to provide a history due to altered mental status. If patients are able to provide a history, they should be questioned regarding symptoms of infection, including fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, confusion, and pain. Patients should also be questioned regarding recent procedures or trauma, which may serve as a nidus for bacteremia. Physical examination should attempt to reveal the source of infection and should include assessment of abdominal pain, respiratory distress, focal neurologic deficits, or skin lesions (such as abscesses or cellulitis).  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform thorough skin assessment:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: While this patient is acutely ill, he is currently protecting his airway and is saturating well on room air. Rapid sequence intubation would be inappropriate management at this time.  
❌ Perform lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is an invasive procedure that can be used to diagnose underlying meningitis. While lumbar puncture may be appropriate if the source of sepsis is not identified, this patient should have a thorough skin examination to assess for an obvious source of infection first.  
❌ Perform bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy can be a useful tool to identify a specific causative organism in patients with signs and symptoms of pneumonia. This is an invasive procedure that is often not necessary. Additionally this patient’s chest radiograph shows no obvious acute pulmonary abnormalities.  
❌ Measure mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2):
Incorrect: SvO2 reflects the amount of oxygen left in the bloodstream following tissue circulation and is typically measured using a pulmonary artery catheter. While this could provide information regarding the tissue extraction of oxygen, it is not generally indicated as part of the evaluation or management of sepsis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for acute decompensated heart failure. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis via an internal jugular venous catheter. The patient has challenging venous anatomy and has had significant difficulty with obtaining venous access in the past. On day 4 of the hospitalization, the patient develops chills and a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 113/74mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness and erythema at the catheter site. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures from two peripheral sites grow Gram-positive cocci in clusters. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Attempt central line lock therapy with IV vancomycin
Remove the central line and start IV vancomycin
Attempt central line lock therapy with IV gentamicin
Remove the central line and start IV caspofungin
Await blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient with an internal jugular venous catheter has fever, chills, exam findings suggesting a line infection, and Gram-positive bacteremia. Along with the absence of findings indicating another source of infection, central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) is the most likely cause of his condition.

All patients with CLABSI should have blood cultures drawn from two separate sites and, subsequently, be started on empiric IV antibiotics. Antifungals may be indicated in patients with predisposing risk factors (e.g. immunocompromised, femoral vein catheterization, Candida colonization). For patients with CLABSI complicated by hemodynamically instability, septic thrombophlebitis, or metastatic infection; the central venous catheter must be removed. For patients with uncomplicated CLABSI, catheter removal is ideal. In cases where it is not feasible, the catheter can be exchanged over a wire or can be retained with antibiotic lock therapy. Lock therapy consists of instilling a high concentration of antibiotic solution into the catheter lumen to eradicate any bacterial biofilm and reduce the risk of recurrence.

A positive response to treatment is evidenced by clinical resolution of symptoms and negative follow-up blood cultures. Lack of blood culture clearance may indicate the presence of a metastatic infection or another source of infection. Further evaluation (e.g. echocardiogram) is required in such cases.  

Option Analysis

✅ Attempt central line lock therapy with IV vancomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Remove the central line and start IV vancomycin:
Incorrect: While this is a reasonable option in most patients with CLABSI (especially if related to septic shock), this patient has had significant difficulty in the past with venous access; therefore, an attempt should first be made to keep the central line.  
❌ Attempt central line lock therapy with IV gentamicin:
Incorrect: Gentamicin does not have significant Gram-positive coverage and would not treat the bacteria growing in this patient’s blood.  
❌ Remove the central line and start IV caspofungin:
Incorrect: Empiric caspofungin and catheter removal is indicated in the management of CLABSI in patients with risk factors for a fungal infection (e.g. immunocompromised, femoral vein catheterization, Candida colonization). This patient has none of these risk factors and blood cultures are not growing fungi.  
❌ Await blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Waiting for blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics delays appropriate treatment and can lead to worse outcomes. Antibiotics can be started based on knowledge of the likely organism.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to worsening bilateral leg swelling. The patient first noticed swelling in both lower extremities last month. It has been worsening since then and lately it has been causing difficulty ambulating. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and morbid obesity. The patient’s only medication is losartan. Temperature is 37.4 ºC (99.3 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 132/85, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation (SpO<sub>2</sub>) is 90% on room air. On pulmonary auscultation, there are bibasilar crackles. There is moderate pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally up to the distal tibias. The patient’s skin is erythematous and cool bilaterally up to the distal tibias as well. Bilateral lower extremity ultrasound shows a non-compressible small saphenous vein on the right. Further workup is pending. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient with bibasilar crackles and bilateral lower extremity edema most likely has congestive heart failure and needs diuresis with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.

Lower extremity (LE) edema is a common presentation for patients and is a feature seen with many different pathologies. Knowing the differential diagnosis and initial management of both unilateral and bilateral edema is important. If unilateral edema is not obvious, calf circumference of both legs can be measured and compared.

LE edema occurs most often due to impaired venous or lymphatic flow, or excessive distribution of fluid into the interstitial space. Obstruction (e.g., deep vein thrombosis or tumor mass effect) anywhere from the pelvis to the lower extremities can impair venous and lymphatic drainage. Venous insufficiency (e.g. varicose veins) and compartment syndrome can also cause impaired venous return. Cirrhosis and congestive heart failure both cause venous congestion which can cause excessive interstitial fluid accumulation. Loss of oncotic pressure, such as from nephrotic syndrome or protein-wasting enteropathy, can also cause lower extremity edema.

Life-threatening or limb-threatening diagnoses such as cardiogenic shock, acute liver failure, and compartment syndrome must be considered early and treated. Otherwise, treatment of edema is guided by the underlying cause. Loop diuretics (e.g., bumetanide, furosemide, torsemide) are very effective at treating edema. Long-term strategies to help with edema include compression stockings or wraps, elevation of the feet, and lower extremity exercises.

Option Analysis

❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: This patient’s lower extremity ultrasound shows a unilateral superficial vein thrombosis, which does not require anticoagulation. In addition, this patient has bilateral lower extremity edema so this clot is unrelated to the current presentation.  
✅ Furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are weak diuretics and should not be used for active diuresis of patients. They should be used for hypertension, or to augment diuresis with loop diuretics (e.g. using metolazone with furosemide).  
❌ Compression stockings:
Incorrect: Compression stockings would be a good long-term strategy for this patient to help reduce lower extremity swelling. However, this patient is volume overloaded as evidenced clinically by the low oxygen saturation and bibasilar crackles, and therefore needs diuresis first for CHF.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin can be used to treat uncomplicated cellulitis. Patients with bilateral lower extremity venous stasis changes, as this patient likely has, can have significant erythema and are often misdiagnosed with bilateral leg cellulitis. This patient is afebrile, has cool skin, and signs of congestive heart failure making cellulitis highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to shortness of breath and lethargy. He also has sharp anterior chest pain. The patient was seen yesterday at an urgent care clinic and was prescribed azithromycin for a suspected upper respiratory infection. Past medical history is notable for mild intermittent asthma treated with an as needed albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 79/54 mmHg, respirations are 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 90% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic. The skin is cool to touch and pale, and capillary refill is delayed. On lung auscultation, there are bibasilar crackles and decreased breath sounds at both lung bases. Pressing on the right upper quadrant of the abdomen causes a prolonged elevation of the jugular venous pulse. Moderate non-pitting edema is present bilaterally up to the proximal tibias. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
There are three types of distributive shock, septic shock, anaphylactic shock, and neurogenic shock. Patients with distributive shock generally have skin that is warm and dry. Fever, infectious symptoms, and leukocytosis may indicate septic shock. Urticaria or an obvious trigger may indicate anaphylactic shock. A known brain or spinal cord injury may indicate neurogenic shock.

Patients with hypovolemic shock,  generally appear severely volume depleted. History may suggest significant volume loss (e.g. profuse diarrhea) in hypovolemic shock, or blood loss (e.g. hematemesis, melena) in hemorrhagic shock. On examination, these patients may have dry mucous membranes, skin tenting (decreased turgor), and poor urine output.

In patients with obstructive shock, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, or known DVT may point to massive pulmonary embolism (“massive” means causing hypotension and does not indicate the clot size). The presence of the Beck triad (hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds) suggests cardiac tamponade. Localized decreased breath sounds, severe dyspnea, and a deviated trachea suggest tension pneumothorax.

Patients with cardiogenic shock, like the patient in this case, generally appear “cold and wet,” unlike the “warm and dry” presentation of distributive shock. Poor cardiac output causes decreased perfusion and results in skin that is cool to the touch. Poor cardiac output and impaired ventricular filling also leads to volume overload. Substernal chest pressure may suggest myocardial infarction. This patient likely has new onset heart failure, which in young patients, may be due to severe viral myocarditis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Ruptured apical bleb:
Incorrect: This is a frequent cause of secondary pneumothorax and could potentially lead to tension pneumothorax, a cause of obstructive shock. This patient’s crackles and decreased breath sounds are symmetric, and the clinical findings and history of preceding viral infection support a diagnosis of viral myocarditis and cardiogenic shock.  
✅ Viral myocarditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial pneumonia:
Incorrect: Severe bacterial pneumonia can lead to septic shock. This patient is afebrile, volume overloaded, and has cool skin to the touch. This supports cardiogenic shock rather than septic shock which is a type of distributive shock.  
❌ Anaphylaxis caused by azithromycin:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis can be delayed and does not always occur immediately. However, this patient is volume overloaded, has no wheezing, and has skin that is cool to the touch. This supports cardiogenic shock rather than anaphylactic shock.  
❌ Spinal cord injury:
Incorrect: Brain or spinal cord injuries can lead to neurogenic shock from impaired vascular tone. Like other types of distributive shock, these patients generally have warm and flushed skin without significant volume overload.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of lethargy. Paramedics report that the patient is currently bed bound in a nursing facility following a left-sided MCA stroke several weeks ago. Additional past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. The patient appears ill and is moaning. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and a large unstageable sacral wound with foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lethargy and multiple medical comorbidities and a likely infected sacral pressure ulcer. She has greater than 2 SIRS criteria which is concerning for underlying sepsis. Patients with sepsis should have a blood lactate measurement as part of their initial assessment.

Sepsis refers to an exaggerated immune response to infection associated with end organ dysfunction and shock (often due to capillary endothelial dysfunction). The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal and may originate from any tissue, initiating a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms.

Patients with sepsis typically present with tachycardia and fever as well as associated symptoms secondary to the source of underlying infection. For example, patients with pneumonia may present with respiratory distress or a cough. Patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms, including fatigue, dizziness, altered mental status, or syncope. This patient is presenting with lethargy and moaning likely from pain from an infected pressure ulcer. When sepsis is suspected, patients should be screened using the SIRS criteria as outlined in the table below. Patients with 2 or more of these abnormal values should undergo further sepsis evaluation with measurement of blood lactate and blood culture analysis as well as administration of broad spectrum antibiotics and IV hydration.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Measure lactic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Place a central venous catheter:
Incorrect: Central venous catheter placement should be considered in patients without appropriate hemodynamic response to intravenous crystalloid administration who likely need vasopressors.  
❌ Place an arterial line:
Incorrect: An arterial line is a useful tool for continuous hemodynamic measurement. It should be considered in patients with sepsis who do not respond appropriately to intravenous crystalloid administration or in those patients who have evidence of septic shock.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Administration of vasoactive agents, such as norepinephrine, should be considered for patients with sepsis who do not respond appropriately to intravenous crystalloid administration.  
❌ Measure mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2):
Incorrect: SvO2 reflects the amount of oxygen left in the bloodstream following tissue circulation and is typically measured using a pulmonary artery catheter. While this could provide information regarding the tissue extraction of oxygen, it is not generally indicated for the treatment of sepsis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner with a one-day history of altered mental status, fever, and chills. The patient was recently diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer and received the first cycle of chemotherapy last week. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient has a 30 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 89/64 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is oriented to place but not to person or time. The patient moves all limbs and has normal reflexes bilaterally. There is no neck stiffness. There is a right chest wall central line in place with marked erythema, tenderness, and purulence at the insertion site. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift and an elevated lactate. Peripheral IV access is established; IV fluids are administered and two sets of blood cultures are obtained from different sites. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and remove the central venous catheter
Order MRI of the brain with gadolinium contrast
Remove the central venous catheter and admit to the intensive care unit for observation
Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, altered mental status, hypotension, and elevated leukocytes and lactic acid most likely has septic shock. The presence of a central venous catheter with local signs of infection at the insertion site and the absence of signs and symptoms indicating another source of infection are consistent with the diagnosis of a complicated central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Complicated CLABSI is defined as CLABSI with septic shock, septic thrombophlebitis, or metastatic infection.

CLABSI is a primary bloodstream infection often associated with septic shock; septic thrombophlebitis; and metastatic infection to the joints, heart valves, and lungs. The initial management of a hemodynamically unstable patient with a suspected CLABSI consists of initiating IV fluids and vasoactive agents if necessary. For all patients with suspected CLABSI; obtain blood cultures from two distinct sites, administer empiric antibiotics covering both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, and remove the central venous catheter to eliminate the source of infection and bacteremia. In hemodynamically stable patients, consider antibiotic lock therapy or line exchange if the central line absolutely has to stay in place.

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and remove the central venous catheter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Although lumbar puncture may be indicated in patients presenting with altered mental status and fever to assess for meningoencephalitis; the lack of neck stiffness and the presence of central venous catheter with findings of erythema, tenderness, and purulence at the insertion site makes the diagnosis of CLABSI more likely.  
❌ Order MRI of the brain with gadolinium contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with fever and altered mental status in the presence of a central venous catheter with signs of infection and the absence of neck stiffness. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of CLABSI; therefore, MRI with gadolinium contrast is not the next best step in management.  
❌ Remove the central venous catheter and admit to the intensive care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Although removal of the central venous catheter is indicated in this case, empiric antibiotics are essential for the management of suspected CLABSI.  
❌ Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Empiric IV antibiotics are indicated in this case as this patient is presenting with sepsis from a CLABSI. The catheter must be removed to eliminate the ongoing bacteremia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 54-year-old-woman is brought to the emergency department due to fever and altered mental status, which started a few hours ago. The patient has breast cancer that was treated with surgical resection, and is currently receiving chemotherapy via an internal jugular venous catheter. The patient’s last chemotherapy was given two weeks ago, and the catheter was removed yesterday. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 120/min, blood pressure is 87/57 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. There is no neck stiffness and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable other than the presence of confusion. Laboratory evaluation shows leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein and lactic acid. Which of the following is necessary to establish the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Blood cultures from two different sites

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and hypotension within 24 hours after removal of a central venous catheter. These findings, in conjunction with elevated white blood cells, C-reactive protein, and lactic acid, are most consistent with a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) complicated by septic shock. Hemodynamically unstable patients (i.e. septic shock) are more likely to have lactic acidosis and symptoms such as altered mental status. The most appropriate test to establish the diagnosis of CLABSI and to guide antibiotic management is blood culture. Other possible sources of infection should also be ruled out.

Ideally, blood cultures should be collected from two different peripheral sites prior to initiation of antibiotics; if that is not possible, they should be drawn from a peripheral and a central site or from a peripheral site on two separate occasions. Diagnosis is made if at least one of the following criteria is met:

  • Growth of a bacterial (e.g. S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, enterococci) or fungal (e.g. Candida sp.) pathogen that is considered a true pathogen from one or more blood cultures.

  • Growth of a common commensal bacterial organism (e.g. coagulase-negative staphylococci) from two different blood cultures in the setting of systemic signs of infection and in the absence of other sites of infection. 
 


Option Analysis

✅ Blood cultures from two different sites:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and hemodynamic instability in the setting of recent internal jugular venous catheter removal. These findings strongly suggest complicated CLABSI. CT scan of the chest would be appropriate if a pulmonary source of infection were suspected.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is indicated for the evaluation for suspected CNS infections, which can present with a fever and altered mental status. The recent internal jugular venous catheter removal and the absence of neck stiffness make the diagnosis of CLABSI more likely.  
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transesophageal echocardiogram is frequently performed in patients diagnosed with CLABSI to rule out endocarditis. It cannot make the diagnosis of suspected CLABSI.  
❌ Procalcitonin level:
Incorrect: Procalcitonin level may be helpful in assessing bacterial pneumonia or guiding antibiotic management in patients with CLABSI. However, it is not specific and cannot establish the diagnosis of CLABSI.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to three days of right leg swelling. Four days ago, the patient developed pain and swelling in the posterior right knee and distal thigh. The patient had an episode of cellulitis of the right leg four years ago after a cat scratch. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and generalized moderate osteoarthritis. Current medications include celecoxib and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is decreased range of motion of the right knee with prominent swelling at the posterior right knee. The right posterior leg is erythematous and slightly warm to touch and is mildly edematous down to the ankle. Skin of the right leg and right foot interdigital spaces is intact. Ultrasound is performed which confirms the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a ruptured Baker cyst, given the history of osteoarthritis and significant pain and swelling of the posterior knee. Baker cyst can be diagnosed with physical examination, but it is often confirmed with ultrasound or MRI of the knee. Treatment includes arthrocentesis of the knee with intra-articular injection of glucocorticoids (e.g. 40 mg triamcinolone acetonide).

Lower extremity (LE) edema, unilateral or bilateral, is a common presentation and is a feature of many different pathologies. Patients with bilateral LE swelling should be asked about other symptoms or signs of volume overload such as dyspnea or abdominal fullness. The patient should be asked about new medications (e.g. calcium channel blockers). Physical examination should focus on looking for systemic findings such as cardiac (e.g. extra heart sound or murmur), abdominal (e.g., ascites, hepatosplenomegaly), or renal abnormalities.

For unilateral LE swelling, assessment should be performed looking for local trauma to the area such as burns or skin breaks. Patients with DVTs may have a personal or family history of blood clots, recent prolonged immobility (e.g., surgery, intercontinental flight), or coagulopathy. Patients with cellulitis often have a fever and a known injury to the skin. Severe pain, paresthesias, or pallor may suggest compartment syndrome. For chronic unilateral LE edema, ask about history of local lymph node resection or radiation, varicose veins, or severe prolonged pain. Physical examination should pay special attention to the skin to look for breaks, erythema, and warmth.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intra-articular corticosteroids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are effective at reducing lower extremity (LE) edema.
