They are used for treating bilateral LE edema in patients with a systemic disease (e.g., cirrhosis, congestive heart failure) and are rarely indicated for unilateral edema. Treatment should focus on the underlying cause of the unilateral edema rather than the edema itself.  
❌ Oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cellulitis can present with unilateral leg swelling, erythema, and warmth. Cephalexin can be used in patients without risk factors for MRSA infection. The time course, symptoms, intact lower extremity skin, posterior knee pain, and history of osteoarthritis makes a ruptured Baker cyst more likely than cellulitis.  
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Cellulitis can present with unilateral leg swelling, erythema, and warmth. Doxycycline can be used in patients with risk factors for MRSA infection. The time course, symptoms, intact lower extremity skin, posterior knee pain, and history of osteoarthritis makes a ruptured Baker cyst more likely than cellulitis.  
❌ Venous sclerotherapy:
Incorrect: This can be used to treat severe venous insufficiency, especially from varicose veins. This patient’s examination doesn’t demonstrate evidence of venous insufficiency (e.g. varicose veins).

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and Crohn disease. While in the ambulance, the patient is given several medications by the paramedics. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient describes new diffuse itching and raised red fluid-filled spots on her arms, legs, and abdomen. Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 78/48 mmHg, respirations are 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 97% on room air. On examination, the patient has labored breathing and wheezing on pulmonary auscultation and hives on her arms, legs, and abdomen. Skin is warm to touch. Digital rectal exam shows a small amount of bright red blood in the rectal vault. Serum tryptase was drawn at the start of the patient’s itching and is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer intramuscular epinephrine and repeat serum tryptase level in 1 hour

questions.solution:
This patient has likely developed anaphylactic shock, a type of distributive shock. Patients often present acutely after a known trigger. Symptoms may include pruritus, urticaria, diffuse flushing, and labored breathing. Physical examination will generally demonstrate skin findings as well as wheezing on pulmonary auscultation. Treatment involves intramuscular or subcutaneous epinephrine and avoiding or stopping the triggering agent. Serum trypsase may not peak for 1-1.5 hours after symptom onset, and therefore should be repeated in 1 hour to help make a diagnosis.

Blood cultures, urinalysis, and imaging can be used to diagnose septic shock. An elevated tryptase confirms anaphylactic shock; however, tryptase may not peak for 1-1.5 hours after symptom onset and may be falsely normal (such as in this patient). Serum tryptase levels ideally should be drawn 1-3 hours after the onset of anaphylaxis symptoms begin to confirm the diagnosis. Brain or spinal cord imaging can confirm CNS injury leading to neurogenic shock.

Laboratory findings in a hypovolemic shock include severe anemia in hemorrhagic shock or signs of volume depletion (e.g. elevated BUN and creatinine) and hemoconcentration (elevated hemoglobin) in non-hemorrhagic shock.

Elevated troponin and ischemic changes on electrocardiogram are used to diagnose myocardial infarction. BNP and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can help diagnose severe heart failure.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, but chest radiograph or ultrasound will confirm pneumothorax. Pulmonary embolism can be suggested by an elevated D-dimer and diagnosed via CT angiography of the chest or V/Q scan. Cardiac tamponade is also a clinical diagnosis, but TTE would show equalization of pressures, RA/RV collapse, and other findings.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intramuscular epinephrine and repeat serum tryptase level in 1 hour:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform colonoscopy with biopsy:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable in a patient with new onset inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, in this patient, if IBD were causing severe GI bleeding and hypotension, it would lead to hemorrhagic shock. This patient has only mild hematochezia and the clinical picture suggests anaphylactic shock and not hypovolemic shock.  
❌ Start intravenous cefepime and vancomycin:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if septic shock were suspected. This patient is afebrile, and the clinical history better supports anaphylactic shock.  
❌ Place a pulmonary artery catheter:
Incorrect: A pulmonary artery catheter allows for invasive hemodynamic monitoring and is not generally recommended in most patients. It can be useful in patients with undifferentiated or mixed shock, especially when there is cardiogenic shock.  
❌ Perform a transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable if cardiogenic shock were suspected. This patient’s clinical picture suggests anaphylactic shock.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis. A central venous catheter and urinary catheter are placed on admission. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, depression, and aortic and mitral valve replacement. Current medications include bupropion, citalopram, and warfarin. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient develops a new fever and is more difficult to awaken than is usual. There is no associated cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or dysuria. Blood tests show leukocytosis. Urinalysis shows 0-3 white blood cells/hpf and is negative for leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and blood. Chest radiograph shows no acute abnormality. Blood cultures are obtained and 2 bottles grow out coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Which of the following tests is needed to confirm the most likely cause of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who has been hospitalized for several days has developed leukocytosis and a new fever. Hospitalized patients who develop a new fever should be promptly evaluated for a nosocomial (healthcare-associated) infection. The main types of nosocomial infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), surgical site infection (SSI), hospital- or ventilator-associated pneumonia (HAP or VAP), and healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). Of note, elderly patients who develop nosocomial infections can often present only with fatigue or altered mental status and without fevers and leukocytosis.

This patient has been hospitalized for several days and has both a central venous catheter and a urinary catheter in place, increasing the risk of a nosocomial infection. Depending upon the suspected source, the workup for nosocomial infection may include obtaining blood and urine cultures; chest imaging; and stool testing. If 1 of 2 blood culture bottles is positive for a pathogenic organism (e.g. S. aureus), this is considered a true infection. If 1 of 2 bottles is positive for a commensal (normal flora) organism such as S. epidermidis, this may reflect contamination of the specimen, and another set of blood cultures should be drawn. If both bottles are positive for a commensal organism, this indicates a true infection.

This patient has two blood culture bottles positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (likely S. epidermidis). Therefore this should be treated as the cause of a true infection, and antibiotics should be started and the central venous catheter should be removed unless there is a major contraindication.  

Option Analysis

✅ No further testing is needed:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: Commensal (normal flora) organisms can sometimes contaminate blood cultures. If 1 of 2 blood culture bottles was positive for these organisms (e.g. coagulase-negative Staphylococcus), then blood cultures should be repeated to ensure that it was a contaminant. However, in this case, where both blood culture bottles are positive, true infection and bacteremia from coagulase-negative Staphylococcus is likely.  
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s urinalysis lacked significant pyuria, leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and blood. She has no suprapubic pain or dysuria. Urinary tract infection is not likely.  
❌ CT of the chest:
Incorrect: CT of the chest can be performed when there is significant concern for pulmonary pathology despite an unrevealing chest radiograph. This patient has no pulmonary symptoms and has bacteremia with organisms that are not associated with pulmonary disease.  
❌ Stool C. difficile toxin assays:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable to perform and could confirm the diagnosis in a patient with suspected C. difficile infection. However, this patient has no watery diarrhea or abdominal pain or tenderness and has 2 blood culture bottles positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Staphylococcus bacteremia is the likely cause of infection.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine well-patient care visit. He has a history of hyperlipidemia and well-controlled hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. He has no history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. He is physically active and follows a healthy diet. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father, who had a myocardial infarction at age 60. Blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, heart rate is 68 beats/min, respiratory rate is 14 breaths/min, and BMI is 27 kg/m². Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are normal. Neurological and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following tests is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A part of the well-patient care visit for this 49-year-old man should include recommending a screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. Screening is recommended for average-risk adults beginning at age 45 to detect precancerous polyps and early-stage cancer, which can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality.        

Several screening options are available, including colonoscopy, which is considered the gold standard due to its ability to visualize the entire colon and remove polyps during the procedure. Colonoscopy should be performed every 10 years in healthy patients with normal findings. Other options for colon cancer screening include stool-based tests (fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test) which should be performed every 1 to 3 years. Computed tomography (CT) colonography (every 5 years) and flexible sigmoidoscopy (every 5 years) may also be used for colon cancer screening. Patients with a family history of colorectal cancer are considered at elevated risk, and screening may need to begin at an earlier age.   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) ultrasound:
Incorrect: This screening test is recommended for males aged 65 to 75 years who have a history of smoking. It is not indicated for asymptomatic males outside of this age range or in patients like this one without a smoking history.
✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prostate-specific antigen (PSA):
Incorrect: PSA screening for prostate cancer is typically recommended for people with prostates aged 50 to 69 using shared decision-making. While this patient is approaching the age range, routine PSA screening is not yet recommended for him based on age. 
❌ Low-dose computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest:
Incorrect: This screening is indicated for individuals aged 50 to 80 with a 20-pack-year smoking history who currently smoke or have quit within the last 15 years. The patient has no history of smoking, making lung cancer screening inappropriate. 
❌ Bone density scan:
Incorrect: Bone density testing (DEXA) is generally recommended for postmenopausal females or males over 50 with additional risk factors for osteoporosis. There is no indication for osteoporosis screening in this healthy 49-year-old man without risk factors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a syncopal episode at home. The patient’s partner at the bedside reports that the patient has been feeling fatigued over the past several days and developed a fever today. The patient has no medical history other than a splenectomy several years ago following a motor vehicle accident. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 75/52 mmHg, pulse is 138/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight is 70 kg (154 lbs). Physical examination shows an ill-appearing man with poor capillary refill. IV access is obtained, and the patient is given 3 L of normal saline, vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and acetaminophen. A central venous catheter and an arterial line are placed. Repeat blood pressure is 83/58 mmHg. Which of the following should be administered next?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue and has evidence of greater than 2 SIRS criteria which is concerning for underlying sepsis. He received appropriate initial management, including administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravenous fluids of more than 30 mL/kg. Despite these measures, the patient continues to have hypotension and should receive vasoactive agents to maintain end organ perfusion.

Sepsis refers to an exaggerated immune response to infection associated with end organ dysfunction and shock. The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal, and may originate from any tissue; this initiates a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms.

Once sepsis has been recognized, appropriate management involves timely measurement of lactate, blood cultures, administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, and continuous blood pressure assessment. Patients with a systolic blood pressure greater than 90 mmHg and a normal lactate should receive intravenous fluids to maintain a urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/h and capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds. Patients with a systolic blood pressure less than 90 mmHg or elevated lactate should receive hemodynamic resuscitation with administration of ≥30 mL/kg of intravenous crystalloids. Following fluid administration, patients should have their mean arterial pressure reassessed. Maintaining a mean arterial pressure ≥65 mmHg is considered an adequate response to fluid resuscitation. A mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg is considered an inadequate response and indicates septic shock. These patients should then receive vasoactive agents, preferably norepinephrine.  

Option Analysis

✅ Norepinephrine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Additional 1 L normal saline:
Incorrect: This patient has already received more than 30 mL/kg of intravenous fluids without an appropriate hemodynamic response. Administration of vasoactive agents is the best next step in management.  
❌ Packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of injury, trauma, or bleeding; the presentation is more consistent with septic shock. Administration of packed red blood cells would be inappropriate management.  
❌ Amikacin:
Incorrect: This patient has already received broad-spectrum antibiotics. Amikacin is rarely used due to its many side effects and is unnecessary at this point.  
❌ Vasopressin:
Incorrect: Vasopressin is considered a second line add-on vasoactive agent for the treatment of septic shock. Norepinephrine is generally the first-line vasoactive agent used.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to severe bilateral lower extremity swelling for the past week. The patient has also noticed facial swelling and decreased urine output over the past few days. There is no associated chest pain or shortness of breath. The patient was recently diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma and has been receiving chemotherapy through a venous port. A few days ago, a clot was found on the port and the patient was started on apixaban. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are no pulmonary crackles, extra heart sounds, or murmurs. The abdomen is soft and non-distended. There is 2+ pitting edema bilaterally up to the proximal tibia. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL (was 0.8 mg/dL two weeks ago). Which of the following tests would be most helpful for determining the etiology of this patient’s lower extremity swelling?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with facial swelling, bilateral lower extremity (LE) swelling, a recent blood clot, and evidence of acute kidney injury (increased creatinine from baseline) likely has nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed with a 24-hour test for protein that shows ≥3.5 grams of protein in the urine per 24 hours. The spot urine protein/creatinine ratio can be used as a surrogate for the 24-hour test. Protein/creatinine ratio >3 is equivalent to a 24-hr urine protein finding of ≥3.5 g/day).

Other causes of bilateral LE edema include heart failure and cirrhosis. Heart failure may present with elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), EKG findings such as voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy, or chest imaging showing pulmonary edema. Echocardiogram may show elevated filling pressures, valvulopathies, impaired diastolic function, or reduced ejection fraction. Cirrhosis may present with elevated transaminases and bilirubin, low albumin and elevated INR. Imaging may suggest cirrhosis if there is diffuse liver nodularity.

For unilateral lower extremity edema, lab tests such as D-dimer (DVT), bacterial cultures (cellulitis), and creatine kinase (compartment syndrome) may be helpful. Venous ultrasound can assess for DVT or venous insufficiency, and MRI can assess for a ruptured Baker cyst.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Serum D-dimer:
Incorrect: This patient already has a known upper extremity DVT so the D-dimer is likely already elevated, which would not be helpful for assessing for a new lower extremity DVT. In addition, lower extremity DVT is generally unilateral and this patient has bilateral edema.  
❌ Serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP):
Incorrect: Serum BNP is elevated due to increased intracardiac wall stretch from volume overload. Though this test can be useful in patients with bilateral lower extremity edema to help diagnose congestive heart failure, this patient’s history, physical exam findings, and blood work with increased creatinine is more concerning for nephrotic syndrome.  
✅ Urinalysis and urine protein/creatinine ratio:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Liver function tests include serum aspartate and alanine aminotransferases (AST and ALT), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT), serum bilirubin, prothrombin time (PT), international normalized ratio (INR), total protein, and albumin. These can be checked if cirrhosis is suspected, as cirrhosis can also present with new lower extremity edema. This patient does not have any risk factors or signs of cirrhosis, making it unlikely, and the elevated creatinine makes nephrotic syndrome more likely.  
❌ Urine chloride:
Incorrect: Urine chloride can be used to help assess a patient’s volume status or determine the etiology in patients with metabolic alkalosis. It does not have diagnostic utility in this case of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to severe shortness of breath and fatigue. The symptoms began four days ago after a mild upper respiratory infection. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient drinks 3 beers per day. Temperature is 36.5 ºC (97.7 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 100/72, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 88% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has labored breathing. The jugular venous pulse is elevated. On auscultation, there are crackles throughout both lungs and an S3 heart sound is heard. There is 2+ pitting edema bilaterally up to the knees. Mental status examination is normal. Laboratory analyses are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Laboratory Test
Value
Serum sodium
130 mEq/L
Serum creatinine
2.8 mg/dL
Serum AST
228 U/L
Serum ALT
112 U/L
Serum total bilirubin  
3.8 mg/dL
Serum INR
1.0
Urine protein/creatinine
0.6
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with new dyspnea, bilateral crackles on lung exam, jugular venous distention (JVD), a new S3 heart sound, and bilateral lower extremity edema likely has acute onset congestive heart failure (CHF). Given the patient’s age and recent upper respiratory infection, this is likely from viral myocarditis. Administration of intravenous furosemide is the most appropriate next step.

Differentiating between the systemic diseases that can cause bilateral lower extremity edema is critical as the workup and management is very different for each one. Liver failure, renal failure, and CHF are the major systemic causes of bilateral lower extremity edema, though there are several other causes.

Liver failure may be chronic (cirrhosis) or acute. True acute liver failure requires the patient to have encephalopathy, coagulopathy (elevated INR or PT), and liver injury (elevated transaminases or bilirubin) and requires emergent transfer to a liver transplant center for evaluation. Presentation of chronic liver failure is more indolent with findings of hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, other stigmata of cirrhosis, and declining liver synthetic function, usually in the setting of an appropriate cause (e.g. alcohol use disorder, hepatitis B virus infection). Renal failure is diagnosed based on elevated serum creatinine or a significant drop in urine output, and may also be chronic or acute. Nephrotic syndromes notoriously cause severe lower extremity edema, but any significant renal failure can cause this. Renal ultrasound, urine protein studies, and even kidney biopsy may be needed to make the diagnosis.

CHF leads to venous congestion and typically presents with dyspnea and fatigue. Symptoms can vary depending on whether right- and left-sided heart failure is present, but many patients will have signs of pulmonary and peripheral edema. Venous congestion can cause renal failure (termed cardiorenal syndrome) and in some cases congestive hepatopathy. This patient’s presentation is concerning for severe acute heart failure and he needs aggressive diuresis  to reduce venous congestion and improve his respiratory status.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: While this test should be performed, however, this patient has strong clinical evidence of new-onset heart failure and needs to be treated immediately with furosemide to reduce venous congestion and improve oxygenation. Heart failure is a clinical diagnosis; an echocardiogram is used to assess severity and etiology but not to diagnose it.  
✅ Administer intravenous furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer intravenous chlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics can be added to loop diuretics to augment diuresis, but they are not used alone for the purpose of diuresis. They can, however, be used alone to treat hypertension.  
❌ Transfer to liver transplant center:
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of acute liver failure (coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and liver injury) and does not need to be evaluated for a transplant. His abnormal liver function tests could be secondary to mild alcoholic hepatitis or congestive hepatopathy from heart failure.  
❌ Administer intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids may be used in certain situations in patients with nephrotic syndrome. This patient’s urine protein/creatinine ratio is not in the nephrotic range (>3).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from home due to shortness of breath and malaise. The patient has altered mental status and history is limited. Past medical history is significant for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hypertension. The current medication list is unavailable. Temperature is 39.1ºC (102.4ºF), pulse is 118/min, blood pressure is 78/55 mmHg, respirations are 22/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on room air. The patient is stuporous on examination. During physical examination the patient coughs up a small amount of bright red blood mixed with sputum. The skin is pale and capillary refill is delayed. The lungs have diffuse rhonchi throughout. Chest radiograph shows bilateral alveolar and interstitial opacities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells
Placement of a pulmonary artery catheter

questions.solution:
This patient presents most likely with septic shock due to pneumonia. Shock is a state of life-threatening inadequate tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery. It usually manifests as hypotension and signs of end organ damage; however, shock can be present even without overt hypotension.

Management begins with assessing and stabilizing the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. Central venous catheters are often placed for ease of venous access or for infusion of vasopressors. A large-gauge IV will provide faster flow rates than a triple lumen central venous catheter, therefore an 18-gauge peripheral IV should be placed in case a large volume of fluid or blood needs to be infused rapidly.

Patients with distributive, hypovolemic, or obstructive shock should receive fluid resuscitation to maintain organ perfusion. Other treatments are specific to the type of shock. Patients with cardiogenic shock should receive positive inotropes and possibly mechanical assist devices; oftentimes, they require diuresis rather than fluid resuscitation.

Septic shock is a type of distributive shock. Sepsis causes widespread endothelial dysfunction of capillaries. If endothelial dysfunction is severe, patients may be unable to maintain adequate organ perfusion, and they develop septic shock. Patients should be fluid resuscitated (≥30 mL/kg of body weight) and receive vasopressors if they remain hypotensive. Administering early antibiotics is crucial in these patients.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient likely has septic shock from pneumonia. The small amount of expectorated blood is likely from pneumonia and not a significant hemorrhage. In addition, the fever suggests septic shock rather than hemorrhagic shock.  
❌ Start norepinephrine infusion:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if the patient’s blood pressure did not respond first to IV fluids as this would indicate septic shock. Patients should be fluid resuscitated (ideally with ≥30 mL/kg of body weight) before starting vasopressors.  
❌ Placement of a pulmonary artery catheter:
Incorrect: A pulmonary artery catheter allows for invasive hemodynamic monitoring and is not generally recommended in most patients. It can be useful in patients with undifferentiated or mixed shock, especially when there is suspicion for cardiogenic shock.  
❌ Administer intramuscular epinephrine:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if anaphylactic shock were suspected. This patient’s fever and chest imaging finding of pneumonia make septic shock the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion and abdominal distention. The patient is not able to  provide a history. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. On physical examination the patient is jaundiced. The heart and lungs are normal upon auscultation. The abdomen is distended, and there is mild non-pitting edema in both feet. Serum transaminases are normal. Serum albumin is 2.5 g/dL and INR is 1.5. Diagnostic paracentesis is performed at bedside. Ascites albumin is 1.0 g/dL and white blood cell count is 300 cells/mm<sup>3</sup> (50% neutrophils and 50% lymphocytes). Administration of which of the following medications is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy which can be managed with oral lactulose. Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) is due to poor liver clearance and subsequent increase in blood ammonia levels. An elevated serum ammonia level may suggest HE but is not diagnostic of HE and should not be trended. HE is treated with lactulose to promote excretion of ammonia in the stool. Rifaximin can be added to help decrease intra-intestinal bacterial production of ammonia.

Paracentesis should be considered in most patients with ascites to allow for ascites fluid studies. The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG), ascites fluid cell count, and cytology are typically ordered. Other studies (e.g. ascites fluid amylase level or total protein) may be useful in certain circumstances. Any patient with confirmed or suspected cirrhosis and a change in clinical status (e.g. confusion, new significant abdominal pain, decompensated cirrhosis) requires a diagnostic paracentesis to look for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis typically only occurs in patients with cirrhosis and can be deadly if not recognized and treated. Neutrophil (PMN) count ≥250 cells/mm3 in the ascites fluid is diagnostic. Portal vein thrombosis can be seen on abdominal venous imaging and is treated with anticoagulation.

Acute liver failure is another life-threatening diagnosis that can present with ascites. Diagnosis of this condition requires encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and elevated transaminases. If a patient has true acute liver failure, they need to be transferred immediately to a liver transplant center for consideration of liver transplant.  

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: PMNs (neutrophils) ≥250 cells/mm3 in ascites fluid is diagnostic of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). This patient has >250 white blood cells in the fluid. However, only 50% of them are neutrophils, so the PMN count is only 150 cells/mm3 and does not represent SBP.  
✅ Oral lactulose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient has jaundice, intra-abdominal fluid, and peripheral edema. In contrast, the lungs are clear to auscultation. These findings are most likely secondary to cirrhosis, rather than heart failure. While patients with cirrhosis and ascites often require oral loop diuretics, IV diuretics are rarely needed and certainly would not be given before other more important issues (e.g. encephalopathy) are corrected first.  
❌ Intravenous prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: This patient’s INR is elevated likely due to abnormal coagulation pathway factor production in the liver. This mild INR elevation is common in patients with cirrhosis and there is no evidence of bleeding. As a result, intravenous prothrombin complex concentration would be inappropriate to administer at the moment.  
❌ Oral pentoxifylline:
Incorrect: This medication can be used for alcoholic hepatitis in patients who cannot receive prednisolone (e.g. due to active gastrointestinal bleeding). With normal transaminases, alcoholic hepatitis is highly unlikely, and the most appropriate next step in management is to treat the encephalopathy. Of note: Transaminases can be normal or only mildly elevated in long-term cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is evaluated on the fourth day of hospitalization. The patient presented with acute gangrenous cholecystitis with resultant septic shock that was treated with intravenous norepinephrine (via a central venous catheter) and piperacillin-tazobactam followed by open cholecystectomy. The patient has not had a bowel movement since the surgery. The patient was recovering well until this morning when she developed moderate abdominal pain and lethargy. On physical exam, there are hypoactive bowel sounds and diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pulmonary examination is normal. Temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. Serum white blood cell count is 22,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Three to five white blood cells/hpf are present in the urine and the stool. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Procalcitonin is 0.03 ng/mL. Blood cultures are sent and come back negative. Urine culture is pending. Which of the following tests is most likely to be positive and confirm the underlying cause of her signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient who has been hospitalized for several days has developed leukocytosis and a new fever. Hospitalized patients who develop a new fever should be promptly evaluated for a nosocomial (healthcare-associated) infection. The main types of nosocomial infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), surgical site infection (SSI), hospital- or ventilator-associated pneumonia (HAP or VAP), and healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).

This patient with abdominal pain and tenderness and fever most likely has developed a C. difficile infection while in the hospital and treated with antibiotics. CDI generally presents with copious watery diarrhea; however, in some cases, like this one where an ileus is present, abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis may be the only indications. In cases where CDI does not present with diarrhea, blood and urine cultures should be obtained to rule out CLABSI and CAUTI. Chest imaging should be performed to rule out HAP or VAP, and surgical sites or wounds should be examined.

If all other tests are negative and CDI is suspected, then stool studies should be performed to look for toxins A and B, as well as GDH (glutamate dehydrogenase) antigens. Rarely a rectal swab can be performed if a stool sample cannot be obtained. If tests for toxins and GDH are both positive, CDI is confirmed. If only one of the tests is positive, then a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) can confirm the diagnosis of CDI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stool C. difficile toxin assay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s urinalysis only shows 3-5 white blood cells/hpf with negative leukocyte esterase and nitrites, and the abdominal exam is significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness and not suprapubic tenderness. This would not be consistent with a urinary tract infection.  
❌ Repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: This is unlikely to provide further information since blood cultures are negative. In addition, the abdominal pain and tenderness indicate that a gastrointestinal source of infection is most likely.  
❌ Induced sputum culture:
Incorrect: This patient has no respiratory symptoms and has normal oxygen saturation on room air, making pneumonia unlikely. Additionally, the very low procalcitonin level points away from bacterial pneumonia as the source of infection.  
❌ Peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: This would be positive if an infection such as malaria, babesiosis, anaplasmosis, or ehrlichiosis was present. These are less likely in this patient than in a nosocomial infection like C. difficile.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of fatigue. She feels severely fatigued on a daily basis since recovering from a viral infection about eight months ago. She also becomes tired after her usual exercise routine and is sometimes too tired to go to work the next day. She reports increased sensitivity to noise and occasional palpitations and lightheadedness when going from lying down to standing up. Temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/68 mmHg. On physical examination, she appears more fatigued than at the beginning of the visit. She has 5/5 strength in all extremities. Oropharyngeal and neck examinations are unremarkable. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL and TSH of 3.6 mIU/L. Which of the following additional clinical elements is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe fatigue that developed after a viral infection and significantly decreased her ability to engage in pre-illness levels of activity such as her usual exercise and work routines. She also has post-exertional malaise, hypersensitivity to external stimuli, and orthostatic intolerance (ie. palpitations). Unrefreshing sleep is a required core symptom for a diagnosis of myalgic encephalomyelitis / chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), which would be consistent with the her signs, symptoms, and examination findings.

Patients who are being evaluated for fatigue should be asked open-ended questions regarding the characteristics, severity, and temporal pattern of the fatigue. It is also important to elicit how fatigue has interfered with aspects of daily life (such as activities, mood, exercise, work, and relationships). Additionally, the history should screen for medications, substance use, and stressors (like domestic violence or illness) that may contribute to fatigue. Symptomatology can point towards specific etiologies and guide further work-up and treatment recommendations.
 

ME/CFS is a chronic, multi-system disease affecting millions of people worldwide. It can present in people of all ages and genders, but most often affects women and those between the ages of 10 to 19 years old and 30 to 39 years old. The vast majority of patients recall an infectious episode near the onset of their symptoms. While it was previously variably defined, ME/CFS now has a set of evidence-based diagnostic criteria.

When ME/CFS is suspected, assessments should be performed to exclude or identify other possible conditions. Comorbidities should be treated and patients should be educated about pacing themselves to stay within their finite energy capacity. Prognosis tends to be poor, with the goal of treatment being to minimize symptoms while maximizing function.  

Option Analysis

✅ Unrefreshing sleep:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sore throat:
Incorrect: Fatigue is a common symptom in infectious diseases such as mononucleosis. While this patient did have an acute viral illness, she does not currently have signs of persistent infection like fever, pharyngitis, or tender lymph nodes.  
❌ Bladder incontinence:
Incorrect: Urinary incontinence can be seen with neuromuscular diseases like multiple sclerosis or myasthenia gravis which can also cause weakness and fatigue. However, this patient’s symptoms do not include weakness or muscular symptoms, and her muscle strength is normal on exam.  
❌ Heavy menstruation:
Incorrect: Anemia can cause fatigue and women who experience menstrual cycles with heavy bleeding are at increased risk for developing iron deficiency anemia, which can manifest as dizziness, tachycardia, and pallor. This patient has a normal hemoglobin.  
❌ Cold intolerance:
Incorrect: Patients with hypothyroidism can present with fatigue. Patients with hypothyroidism may also have weight gain and cold intolerance, and physical exam might reveal the presence of a goiter, bradycardia, dry skin, and fragile hair.  This patient’s TSH is normal.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a partner, reporting a fall down the stairs while carrying laundry 2 days ago, now with severe wrist pain. No other injuries or loss of consciousness are reported. The partner repeatedly comments, “She’s always been clumsy.” There is no significant past medical or surgical history, no current medications, and no known drug allergies. Review of medical records reveals two prior emergency department visits in the past 6 months for a concussion and rib contusion, both attributed to accidental falls. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient appears anxious and frequently glances toward the partner. There is tenderness and swelling over the left wrist with limited range of motion, along with faint facial bruising. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of concern?

choices.text: Circumferential bruises on the patient’s wrists bilaterally

questions.solution:
This patient’s repeated injuries and the partner’s dismissive comments raise concern that the injuries may not be accidental. Injuries that are inconsistent with the reported mechanism, including patterned or constriction bruises, should heighten suspicion for intimate partner violence (IPV). In this context, circumferential bruises on both wrists are inconsistent with a fall down the stairs, raise concern for restraint-related injury, and should prompt evaluation for IPV.   

When evaluating possible intimate partner violence or sexual assault, perform a careful assessment that documents all injuries, with attention to patterns that are inconsistent with the history. Screen for psychological and physical abuse, and assess immediate safety and available supports. Use a trauma-informed approach that is respectful, nonjudgmental, and supportive to facilitate disclosure and connection to resources.   

Findings that should raise suspicion include repeated emergency visits, inconsistent explanations, injuries in various stages of healing, patterned bruising such as fingertip or ligature marks, head or neck trauma, and visible fearfulness. Anxiety, depression, chronic pain, and other psychosocial concerns are common but nonspecific. During the examination, emphasize privacy, choice, and control. Describe each step and obtain verbal consent as the examination proceeds. Ask partners or caregivers to leave the room to allow private questioning and examination, recognizing that a companion may resist leaving and may pose a safety risk.   

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources   

Option Analysis

❌ Bruises on the shins bilaterally:
Incorrect: Shin bruises are common accidental injuries and are not specific for abuse. Such injuries could occur in the described fall and would not be highly suspicious for intimate partner violence, the diagnosis of concern.  
❌ Positive chlamydia test:
Incorrect: A positive chlamydia test indicates recent infection, which may be acquired through consensual or nonconsensual sexual activity. On its own, it is nonspecific and does not confirm intimate partner violence, the diagnosis of concern in this case. 
❌ Positive pregnancy test:
Incorrect: A positive pregnancy test suggests pregnancy and is an important clinical finding, but it does not provide direct evidence of physical or sexual abuse.  
❌ Long-standing history of depression:
Incorrect: Depression may result from many causes, including past trauma, but it is not specific for intimate partner violence. 
✅ Circumferential bruises on the patient’s wrists bilaterally:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 10-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department accompanied by her older sibling for evaluation of diaper rash. The 18-year-old sibling states that the patient has been crying and inconsolable for the past two days due to the rash. They report the patient has otherwise been in her usual state of health. The patient lives with her sibling and both parents. The sibling states their parents have been out of town for the past few days. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and is behind on well-child care. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/42 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is crying in her sibling’s arms. The patient is unwashed and is wearing stained and ill-fitting clothing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. The patient has evidence of severe diaper dermatitis with denuded skin. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the probable cause of this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Bruising around the torso, ears, and neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of neglect, including severe diaper dermatitis, evidence of inappropriate clothing, and poor hygiene. Neglect includes insufficient medical, nutritional, educational, or emotional care. History of poor school attendance and delays in care as well as physical examination findings of poor weight gain, dental caries, and severe diaper dermatitis can be seen in patients who experience neglect.        

The history and physical examinations help identify the specific type of non-accidental trauma that children have suffered. Signs of physical abuse include trauma in nonmobile infants or fractures in non-ambulatory children. Patients may present with suspicious injuries such as handprints, bite marks, or cigarette burns, or appear in a suspicious pattern like circumferential burns (see below). Patients who have been physically abused may have marks or bruising in unusual locations such as on the torso, neck, mouth, or ears. Non-accidental trauma should be suspected when fractures of the posterior or lateral ribs, scapulae, or vertebrae are present if metaphyseal “corner” or “bucket-handle” fractures are seen on radiographs, or if there is evidence of multiple fractures in various stages of healing.        

Sexual abuse can cause age-inappropriate sexual behaviors, dysuria, enuresis, or genital injuries. Patients with psychological abuse may present with somatic complaints, anxiety or depression, declining school performance, or developmental regression. Medical child abuse occurs when the caregiver is responsible for a child receiving unnecessary and potentially harmful medical care and may be suspected when caregivers repeatedly seek care and are unsatisfied with the care provided.        

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.  


Image 1. Handprints 


Image 2. Cigarette burns 

Option Analysis

✅ Poor weight gain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Circumferential burn marks  :
Incorrect: This patient's history and physical exam are concerning for neglect due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, rather than physical abuse. Physical abuse should be suspected in children with circumferential burn marks, while poor weight gain is commonly associated with neglect. 
❌ Genital injury:
Incorrect: Genital injury may be seen in patients who experience sexual abuse. This patient has a history and findings that are more consistent with neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, which is often associated with poor weight gain.  
❌ Bruising around the torso, ears, and neck:
Incorrect: This patient's history is more concerning for neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, rather than physical abuse. Poor weight gain is commonly associated with neglect. 
❌ Developmental regression :
Incorrect: Developmental regression can occur in older children who experience psychological abuse. This patient has a history and exam that are more consistent with neglect, due to inadequate provision of the child’s basic needs, which is often associated with poor weight gain.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her parent with a concern for repeated sexual abuse. The patient's parent states that the patient reports several instances this past month when the patient’s 17-year-old stepbrother had sexually inappropriate contact with the patient. The patient reports the stepbrother touched her breasts without her consent on several occasions, the last of which was one week ago. She denies any touching beneath her underwear. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication daily. She primarily lives at home with her mother but does spend occasional weekends with her father, stepmother, and stepbrother. She is in sixth grade and performing well academically. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious with poor eye contact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Skin examination does not reveal any suspicious bruising or injury. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of sexual abuse. Once medically stabilized, the first step in treatment of all patients presenting with abuse involves informing Child Protective Services. Child Protective Services (CPS) functions to gather additional information about incidents and ensure safety plans for patients and their families.        

In addition to calling CPS, all pediatric patients with concern for abuse should have their caregivers informed and be treated by a multidisciplinary team (including behavioral health services, case managers, and specialists in the treatment of pediatric abuse).        

Sexual abuse will often involve additional medical workups and treatment. Pediatric patients concerned for sexual abuse should be assessed for signs of physical injury and pregnancy or infection requiring treatment. If certain indicators are present, patients should undergo a sexual assault examination within 72-120 hours of the incident to document findings of injury. This examination should be performed by a trained provider, chaperone, and additional caregiver at bedside. Patients should also be offered screening and empiric treatment for sexually transmitted infections.        

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Report to Child Protective Services (CPS):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consult psychiatry :
Incorrect: A multidisciplinary approach to the care of patients with sexual abuse should involve behavioral health services. However, mandatory reporting to child protective services takes precedence.  
❌ Consult case manager:
Incorrect: A multidisciplinary approach to caring for patients with sexual abuse should involve social work services. However, mandatory reporting to child protective services takes precedence. 
❌ Sexually transmitted infection (STI) testing:
Incorrect: STI testing is a core component in the management of sexual assault patients. However, this patient denies any genital involvement. Child protective services should be called next to investigate the situation.  
❌ Skeletal survey:
Incorrect: A skeletal survey does not need to be obtained in this pediatric patient who presents with concern for sexual abuse. A skeletal study is usually obtained when there is suspected physical abuse in those less than two years of age. For this case, the next step in management is getting child protective services involved.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the pediatrician in autumn for a well-child visit accompanied by her parent. There are no changes to her health since the last visit, but they disclose that she wants to become sexually active and would like to discuss contraception options. She eats a variety of foods and rarely consumes sugary drinks. Her periods are regular, and her last menstrual period was one week ago. Recommended vaccinations prior to this visit are up-to-date, and her last hearing test was at age 12. She had a normal complete blood count and lipid panel at age 11. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, weight is 128 pounds, height is 64 inches, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. On physical examination, she is pleasant and engaging in communication. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. In addition to performing a chaperoned genital examination and discussing safe sexual practices and contraceptive options, which of the following is most appropriate to include at this visit?

choices.text: Papanicolaou test     Discuss academic performance     Lipid panel     Seasonal influenza vaccine
Sexually transmitted infection screening     Hearing screening     Papanicolaou test     Discussion about online bullying

questions.solution:
The well-check visit for this 16-year-old adolescent should include a meningococcal vaccine and discussion of self-care, including oral hygiene. An HIV test can be offered at this time as well. This patient is due for a hearing test, as her last one was before the age of 15. Influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations should be offered based on the season. Therefore, this patient should be offered the Meningococcal vaccine and a hearing and HIV screening; oral hygiene should be discussed as well.       

The well-child visit for an adolescent is an opportunity for healthcare providers to engage with patients and their caregivers about a number of components of health promotion, including routine screenings, immunizations, and conversations about health and behavioral topics. All adolescents should have a discussion about self-care at their well-check, including topics such as healthy eating, physical activity, sleep, and oral hygiene. Biologically female patients should be asked about their menstrual patterns and any symptoms related to menses. Timing of immunizations is age-specific but will include a Tdap, HPV vaccine series, and meningococcal vaccines during the adolescent years, in addition to seasonal influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations.        

Recommended screening tests for an adolescent include a lipid panel at ages 9-11 and 17-21, a hearing test (once between ages 11-14, 15-17, and 18-21), and a vision test at ages 12 and 15. A hemoglobin level can be used to screen for anemia if the patient has risk factors, such as a diet that’s low in iron or menorrhagia. It is also recommended to screen adolescents for hepatitis C once between ages 18-79 and for HIV once between ages 15-18. Sexually active adolescents should be offered screening for sexually transmitted infections.  

Option Analysis

✅  Meningococcal vaccine     Hearing screening     HIV screening     Discuss oral hygiene    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Papanicolaou test     Discuss academic performance     Lipid panel     Seasonal influenza vaccine    :
Incorrect: Seasonal influenza vaccination and review of academic performance are appropriate at a 16-year-old well-check. A chaperoned genital examination should be done; however, a Papanicolaou test is not indicated until at least age 21. This patient is not due for her next lipid panel until age 17-21. 
❌  DTap vaccine     Meningococcal vaccine     Hepatitis C screening     Discuss sleep habits    :
Incorrect: The meningococcal vaccine and discussion of sleep habits would be appropriate at a 16-year-old well-check. However, the DTap vaccine is last given by the age of 6. Tdap vaccines are given at age 11 and either Td or Tdap is given every 10 years thereafter. Hepatitis C should be screened for once between ages 18 and 79. 
❌  Sexually transmitted infection screening     Hearing screening     Papanicolaou test     Discussion about online bullying    :
Incorrect: A hearing screen is indicated at this time as well as a discussion of online bullying. Screening for sexually transmitted infections is appropriate given this patient reports sexual activity. A chaperoned genital examination should be done; however, a Papanicolaou test is not indicated until at least age 21. 
❌  Discuss oral hygiene     Lead level      HPV vaccine     Discussion about healthy eating    :
Incorrect: Discussion of oral hygiene and healthy eating are indicated at this visit; however, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. HPV vaccination could be offered at this age if not already given but it is usually offered starting at age 9 and it is noted that this child is up to date on vaccines.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the primary care office for a well-child visit accompanied by his parent. They report no changes to his health since his last visit. He is doing well in school and exercises five days per week. Vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 108/64 mmHg, weight is 125 pounds, height is 68 inches, and BMI is 19 kg/m2. He is pleasant and alert with good eye contact and is engaging in conversation. The physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is a component of an evidence-based approach to promoting health in this adolescent patient?

choices.text: Screen the patient for depression and suicidal ideation
Interview the patient only when parents are present
Assure complete confidentiality about everything the patient says
Avoid asking about access to weapons and avoid counseling about firearm safety because of the second amendment

questions.solution:
This 14-year-old adolescent presenting for a well-child visit should be asked about self-harm and depression. An effective way to open this conversation is to ask about the child’s mood for the previous two weeks to determine whether they’re experiencing any symptoms of depression or anxiety. The provider can also ask how the child expresses their feelings, including any coping strategies for dealing with strong emotions, and ask if they have trusted people to confide in. Adolescent patients should also be screened for depression and suicidal ideation. The Patient Health Questionnaire-A (PHQ-A) is a survey that can be administered to adolescents to screen, diagnose, and monitor depression.        

A core aspect of health promotion in the well-child visit for an adolescent is the HEADSSS assessment. HEADSSS is a mnemonic used to highlight the important aspects of the patient interview and stands for Home; Education and Employment; Activities; Drugs and substance use; Sexuality, Gender Identity, and Relationships; Self-harm and Depression; and Safety. It is ideal for this part of the patient interview to be conducted without the parent present to build autonomy, strengthen the physician-patient relationship, and allow the child to ask questions they might otherwise be reluctant to ask. The environment should be non-judgmental and supportive so that the adolescent can openly express concerns about sensitive issues. The table below includes the key topics to cover during the HEADSSS assessment.        

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.  




Option Analysis

✅ Screen the patient for depression and suicidal ideation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Interview the patient only when parents are present  :
Incorrect: Adolescents should be offered the opportunity to have a discussion with their healthcare provider without parents present as it builds autonomy, strengthens the physician-patient relationship, and allows the child to ask questions they might otherwise be reluctant to ask. 
❌  Avoid discussing body image :
Incorrect: The well-child check is an important time to discuss body image, using the adolescent’s perceptions about weight and appearance to help identify signs of disordered eating. 
❌ Assure complete confidentiality about everything the patient says:
Incorrect: Certain things a patient may disclose, especially regarding self-harm or thoughts of harming others, require reporting. A physician should not provide reassurance that everything said is fully confidential as this would erode trust if the physician then has to disclose information. 
❌ Avoid asking about access to weapons and avoid counseling about firearm safety because of the second amendment :
Incorrect: Asking about whether an adolescent has access to weapons, especially guns, is an important part of the safety assessment that can be done at every well-child visit, and it is not prohibited by the law or by the second amendment.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The patient has no previous surgical history. Sevoflurane is used for anesthesia. Thirty minutes into the procedure, the patient becomes tachycardic and tachypneic. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On physical examination, the patient has jaw muscle tightness. Hypercarbia is noted on end-tidal CO2 monitoring. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperthermia soon after initiating a volatile anesthetic (sevoflurane) is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. Masseter muscle rigidity and a high-end-tidal CO2 further support the diagnosis.

This condition is caused by abnormal calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and is associated with genetic defects in ryanodine or dihydropyridine receptors. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

Vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperthermia. Physical examination may demonstrate masseter muscle or generalized muscle rigidity. Hypercarbia (despite adequate ventilation), evidenced by an increased end-tidal CO2 measurement, is a crucial finding. Prompt recognition of malignant hyperthermia is essential as it carries a high mortality rate if not managed quickly.

Once malignant hyperthermia is suspected, dantrolene should be administered immediately. Dantrolene works on ryanodine receptors to inhibit calcium release and muscle contraction. Additional acute management should include discontinuing the triggering anesthetic, hyperventilation, increasing the oxygen flow rate, and initiating cooling measures if the patient’s temperature is > 39 °C. If not already in place, endotracheal intubation, arterial line, and urinary catheter placement are also necessary.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer dantrolene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine is used for treating serotonin syndrome which is characterized by mental status changes, autonomic hyperactivity, and neuromuscular abnormalities caused by drugs that increase serotonin activity in the central nervous system. However, this patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ Administer succinylcholine:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. Succinylcholine is a depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant and a “triggering” agent for malignant hyperthermia, not a treatment for it.  
❌ Administer diltiazem:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia caused by unregulated calcium release in skeletal muscle cells. Calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem, should be avoided.  
❌ Administer bromocriptine:
Incorrect: Bromocriptine is used for treating neuroleptic malignant syndrome, characterized by mental status changes, rigidity, fever, and dysautonomia caused by antipsychotic medications. However, this patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia caused by anesthetic medication.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy and receiving desflurane for anesthesia maintenance. An hour into the procedure, the patient becomes tachycardic. Temperature is 39.3 °C (102.7 °F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On examination, generalized muscle rigidity is noted. The patient is over-breathing the ventilator, and end-tidal CO2 is high. An ECG is obtained. Which of the following would most likely be seen on the ECG?
questions.solution:
This patient’s hyperthermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and muscle rigidity during anesthesia administration with desflurane is concerning for malignant hyperthermia. This is an anesthetic complication with a high mortality rate if not promptly treated. Certain anesthetics can trigger excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscles in genetically-sensitive individuals. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

In addition to performing a physical examination, an initial evaluation for suspected malignant hyperthermia should include obtaining end-tidal CO2 measurement and an ECG. An elevated end-tidal CO2 despite adequate ventilation is a key finding, as it demonstrates increased CO2 production from hypermetabolism. Additionally, potassium release due to muscle cell destruction can result in hyperkalemia, disrupting the heart's normal electrophysiologic function. This may include ECG changes, such as peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, or ventricular arrhythmias.

Laboratory studies may show hyperkalemia, elevated creatine kinase (from muscle breakdown), and lactic acidosis. Blood gasses would likely show mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. Coagulation studies should also be sent, as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a potential complication. Urinalysis might show myoglobinuria due to rhabdomyolysis.

Remember, while these studies are important in identifying and managing malignant hyperthermia manifestations and complications, they should not delay acute management. This includes discontinuing the offending anesthetic agent, administering dantrolene, and addressing the patient’s hyperthermia and hypercarbia.  

Option Analysis

❌ ST elevations:
Incorrect: ST elevations can occur in myocardial infarction and pericarditis. However, the patient’s history and examination are more consistent with malignant hyperthermia.  
✅ Peaked T waves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ J waves (Osborn waves):
Incorrect: Osborn waves can occur with hypercalcemia. While malignant hyperthermia is associated with increased myoplasmic calcium within the muscles, it is not associated with hypercalcemia in the blood. It is associated with hyperkalemia.  
❌ Prominent U waves:
Incorrect: U waves can be normal in patients without pathology but are frequently associated with pathology. Prominent U waves are seen with electrolyte abnormalities, such as hypokalemia. However, malignant hyperthermia is associated with hyperkalemia.  
❌ Notched P wave:
Incorrect: Notched P waves usually indicate left atrial enlargement. They are not related to malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus is admitted for evaluation of discharge from a surgical incision site. He had emergent exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy 8 days ago after sustaining abdominal injuries in a motor vehicle collision. His postoperative course was complicated by the development of a surgical site infection with a small abscess 4 days postoperatively treated with antibiotics and drainage. He was bending down to pick something up and heard a popping sound, followed by the sensation of bulging at the site of his incision with a large amount of pink-colored discharge. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 110/minute, and blood pressure is 92/60 mmHg. Which of the following findings on physical examination of the abdomen would warrant emergent surgical intervention?

choices.text: Complete incisional separation with visible bowel loops
Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with clear discharge and no surrounding erythema
Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with bloody discharge and no surrounding erythema

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of serosanguinous discharge from his recent surgical incision site, after experiencing a popping sensation and bulging at the incision site. On physical examination, he has a fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. If complete separation of his incision site with visible bowel loops is seen on physical exam, the diagnosis would be deep fascial wound dehiscence complicated by evisceration (herniation of intra-abdominal organs through the open wound).  

Complete fascial dehiscence (complete separation of wound edges) has a mortality rate of 10 percent and poses an increased risk for herniation of the bowel and strangulation. Complete fascial dehiscence and evisceration both require immediate surgical evaluation. The wound can be covered with sterile saline dressing while the patient is prepared for surgery.



Dehiscence occurs when there is a partial or total separation of wound edges due to a failure of proper wound healing. It usually occurs in the early stages of wound healing, approximately 5 to 8 days following surgery. Risk factors for dehiscence include poor perfusion (due to vascular diseases), infection of the wound site, increased abdominal pressure, diabetes, malnutrition, smoking, and obesity. It is typically caused by mechanical stresses like lifting more than 15 pounds. If this patient was stable and without signs of evisceration, CT with contrast could be obtained to evaluate the presence and size of the fascial defect.  

Another postoperative wound complication that warrants emergent surgical intervention is an anterior neck hematoma. This should be suspected in patients who present with progressive difficulty breathing after undergoing neck surgery. The limited space in the neck for swelling and fluid leads to easy compression of the airway which is a life-threatening complication.

Option Analysis

✅ Complete incisional separation with visible bowel loops:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Erythema around the incision site:
Incorrect: Erythema around the incision site is a sign of a possible infectious process and surgical site infection. A superficial site infection with an abscess might need localized drainage but would not require an emergent procedure.
❌ Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with clear discharge and no surrounding erythema:
Incorrect: This can be seen with a seroma. Further imaging with ultrasound should be done to confirm the diagnosis before interventions such as observation or drainage. Emergent surgery would not be necessary in most cases.
❌ Visualization of a tract opening:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen with a fistula with likely continuous drainage. Further evaluation with imaging such as CT or fistulogram would be needed before surgery if indicated.
❌ Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with bloody discharge and no surrounding erythema:
Incorrect: This finding can be seen with a hematoma. Hematomas are more common in patients with risk factors for bleeding (such as history of coagulopathy or use of anticoagulation medications). Hematomas can be treated with observation or drainage. Emergent surgery would not be necessary in most cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is seen in the post-anesthesia care unit after an uncomplicated surgery. The patient describes abdominal distension and diffuse abdominal pain radiating to the bilateral shoulders. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. BMI is 43 kg/m2. The sutures are intact and there is no bulging or drainage at the surgical site. Serial upright chest radiographs demonstrate increasing air under the diaphragm. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this postsurgical complication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening diffuse abdomen and bilateral shoulder pain shortly after surgery. The patient’s serial chest radiographs show increasing air under the diaphragm. These findings are consistent with pneumoperitoneum and CO2 diaphragmatic irritation that can occur as a complication of minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery. With minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery there can be postoperative abdominal pain from peritoneal stretching and diaphragmatic irritation associated with carbon dioxide insufflation and pneumoperitoneum. This generally presents within hours after surgery, and it typically resolves within a few days after laparoscopic surgery.

There can be other complications related to laparoscopic surgery. Complications can occur with the insertion of laparoscopic equipment into the abdominal cavity. These can Include vascular injury, gastrointestinal perforation, solid visceral injury, and nerve injury. Postsurgical complications can include port-site hernia and surgical site infection.

Surgical site infection is a common complication after any type of abdominal surgery. Surgical site infection is classified as superficial SSI, deep incisional SSI, and organ/space surgical site infection. Symptoms of superficial SSI include localized swelling, warmth, drainage, wound breakdown and separation, and erythema and pain at the incision site. Deep incisional SSI can be diagnosed when there is infection involving the fascia or muscle. Patients with deep SSI typically do not have skin changes. They can have localized swelling, warmth, drainage, and wound breakdown. Patients with organ/space surgical site infections present with fever and pain in the region of the abdomen where the operation was performed. Imaging can show an abscess in the cavity of the involved organ.

Option Analysis

✅ Minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bowel resection with anastomosis:
Incorrect: Anastomotic leak can be a complication of bowel resection with anastomosis. This patient's presentation is more consistent with pneumoperitoneum from CO2 insufflation.
❌ Heavy lifting done postoperatively:
Incorrect: Heavy lifting in the postoperative period can lead to fascial dehiscence. Which can present with wound opening and can lead to complete dehiscence with a bulge at the surgical site and serosanguinous drainage.
❌ Use of narcotic medication postoperatively:
Incorrect: Patients can develop an ileus after surgery which presents with obstipation and difficulty tolerating oral intake along with abdominal pain. The use of narcotics postoperatively can worsen this condition.
❌ Open abdominal procedure:
Incorrect: CO2 gas used during laparoscopic surgery can lead to pneumoperitoneum and diaphragmatic irritation. It is not used in open surgery.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling down a flight of stairs. The patient was walking home when she lost balance, fell backward, and slid down a flight of stairs approximately 10 feet in height. The patient is currently experiencing severe pain in the posterior left thorax, abdomen, and flank. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 148/89 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple areas of bruising and skin lacerations on the posterior left thorax, and a large area of bruising located over the left flank region. Abdominal exam is significant for a soft abdomen without tenderness to palpation, rebound, or guarding. Lower extremity pulses are present an equal bilaterally. Hemoglobin is 9.5 g/dL. CT imaging is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with left-sided thorax, abdomen, and flank pain after falling down a flight of stairs. Physical examination shows a prominent area of ecchymosis and soft tissue lacerations over the left flank. Imaging reveals fluid accumulation in the left retroperitoneal space. In combination, these findings indicate a retroperitoneal hematoma.

Retroperitoneal hematoma can be caused by injury to parenchymal tissue or vascular structures secondary to blunt trauma (like motor vehicle accidents) or a penetrating injury (like stab or gunshot wounds). Retroperitoneal hematomas may also occur in patients who have undergone percutaneous or endovascular interventions. They may also occur spontaneously in patients on anticoagulation therapy.

In traumatic retroperitoneal hematomas, patients may appear pale and have visible traumatic injuries (e.g. stab wounds, skin laceration). They may also present with a flank (Grey-Turner sign), inguinal (Fox sign), and scrotal (Bryant sign) ecchymosis on the side of the hematoma. Laboratory testing usually shows decreased hemoglobin, and it can show an increased creatinine due to displacement of the kidney by the hematoma.

Patients with non-traumatic retroperitoneal hematomas can also present with flank, inguinal, and scrotal ecchymosis. Puncture sites may be present if the patient has had a recent percutaneous procedure. Laboratory testing may show an increase in coagulation parameters (e.g. PT, PTT, INR) if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retroperitoneal hematoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acute aortic dissection:
Incorrect: An acute aortic dissection can cause chest, abdominal, and flank pain; however, the visualized segment of the abdominal aorta is unremarkable, and this patient is not hypotensive and has normal lower extremity pulses.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: Rectus sheath hematomas are located in the anterior abdominal wall, and are not seen or palpated on this patient’s physical exam. Moreover, imaging does not reveal pathology of the anterior abdominal wall.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: A compression fracture of the vertebral body can present with acute back pain and tenderness at the injured vertebral body. The visualized vertebral body looks grossly normal on the CT without evidence of fracture or deformity, and this image demonstrates a retroperitoneal hematoma which is likely the cause of this patient’s left flank pain.  
❌ Liver laceration:
