Incorrect: The liver is often damaged in cases of blunt trauma to the abdomen. However, liver injury would be associated with right-sided abdominal pain and overlying soft tissue injury on the right.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided back pain. The pain developed abruptly seven hours ago and has progressively worsened in severity. The patient has not had a recent traumatic injury or exercise-related injury. She has no increased urinary frequency, dysuria, or difficulty urinating. Medical history is notable for right leg deep vein thrombosis for which the patient is taking apixaban. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 152/87 mmHg. Physical examination shows a large ecchymosis over the left lateral flank. Hemoglobin is 10.6 g/dL  and creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL. CT imaging reveals a dense fluid collection in zone II of the left retroperitoneal space. There is no evidence of kidney injury or active contrast extravasation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with left-sided pain in the setting of current anticoagulant use and imaging revealing a dense fluid collection in the left retroperitoneal space. These findings are most consistent with a non-traumatic retroperitoneal hematoma. The next best step would be to discontinue the anticoagulant apixaban.

Non-traumatic retroperitoneal hematomas are typically treated with medical management, which includes intravenous hydration, pain medications, and reversal of anticoagulation. Patients may require blood transfusions if the hemoglobin levels drop or if patients develop hypotension refractory to IV hydration. Additionally, patients should be monitored with serial abdominal examinations. Patients who have uncontrolled bleeding, hemodynamic instability, or contrast extravasation seen on imaging may need angioembolization.

Patients with traumatic retroperitoneal hematomas who are hemodynamically unstable typically require emergent laparotomy, which can not only stop the retroperitoneal bleeding but address any other injuries that are present. Patients with traumatic retroperitoneal hematomas who are hemodynamically stable may be treated with laparotomy or angioembolization.  

Option Analysis

❌ Angioembolization:
Incorrect: This patient who is on anticoagulation presents with a left retroperitoneal hematoma. The patient is hemodynamically stable and imaging does not reveal a site of active bleeding that can be embolized. Therefore, the patient should be treated conservatively by discontinuing anticoagulation, administering intravenous fluid, performing serial abdominal exams, and managing pain.  
❌ Emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a left retroperitoneal hematoma. The patient is hemodynamically stable and should be treated conservatively by discontinuing anticoagulation, administering intravenous fluid, performing serial abdominal exams, and managing pain.  
✅ Discontinuation of anticoagulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transfusion of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: Common indications for transfusion of packed red blood cells include a low hemoglobin (typically less than 7 g/dL) and uncontrolled bleeding. This patient is hemodynamically stable with mild anemia. Therefore, a transfusion with packed red blood cells is not indicated, and the patient should have the hemoglobin trended over time and serial abdominal examinations performed.  
❌ Renal doppler ultrasound:
Incorrect: Retroperitoneal hematoma can lead to obstructive uropathy. However, this patient has a normal creatinine and no evidence of kidney injury on CT.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of a painless, soft mass in the right scrotum that has been gradually increasing in size over the past six months. The mass becomes more prominent when he stands and coughs, but disappears when he is lying flat. He has not had a fever, chills, weight loss, dysuria, or urinary frequency. His past medical history is unremarkable. The patient lifts heavy weights regularly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender mass in the scrotum that is easily reduced into the inguinal canal. The mass becomes more prominent with standing and Valsalva maneuver. The mass does not transilluminate with the application of light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a six-month history of a gradually enlarging, painless, reducible soft scrotal mass, which becomes more noticeable with standing, coughing, and the Valsalva maneuver. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of an indirect inguinal hernia.
 

There are two types of inguinal hernias: indirect and direct. Indirect inguinal hernias result from the congenital persistence of the processus vaginalis, a peritoneal outpouching that typically disappears during development. These hernias follow the inguinal canal and may extend into the scrotum in males or the labia majora in females. In contrast, direct inguinal hernias arise from acquired weaknesses in the transversalis fascia, typically within Hesselbach's triangle, which is formed inferiorly by the inguinal ligament, laterally by the inferior epigastric vessels, and medially by the rectus abdominis muscle. These do not extend into the scrotum or labia majora. Common risk factors for the development of an inguinal hernia include male sex, age younger than 5 years or older than 75 years, family history of inguinal hernia in first-degree relatives, impaired collagen metabolism, and previous history of benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatectomy.

Direct and indirect inguinal hernias often present as painless bulges or masses in the groin that enlarge with increased intra-abdominal pressure; such as during standing, coughing, or straining. In some cases, the mass can be reducible, meaning it can be gently pushed back into the abdomen. However, if it becomes incarcerated or strangulated, it may present as a tender, irreducible mass with signs and symptoms of ischemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Indirect inguinal hernia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Epididymitis:
Incorrect: Epididymitis presents with a tender, swollen epididymis and may be accompanied by fever, chills, and urinary symptoms.  
❌ Hydrocele:
Incorrect: A hydrocele refers to a fluid-filled sac surrounding the testicle that transilluminates on examination, in contrast to this patient’s mass which does not transilluminate and is likely an inguinal hernia.  
❌ Testicular cancer:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer usually presents as a painless, firm, non-reducible testicular mass.  
❌ Varicocele:
Incorrect: Varicoceles refer to dilated veins in the pampiniform plexus that feel like a "bag of worms" on examination of the scrotum.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care clinic for evaluation of a 2-month history of constant dull pain and a bulge in his right groin. The bulge becomes more prominent with standing and lifting heavy objects, but resolves with lying flat. He denies fever, nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is significant for a reducible, non-tender bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament. The mass is more prominent when the patient stands or performs the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-month history of constant dull pain in the groin and physical examination findings of a reducible, non-tender bulge in the right inguinal area above the inguinal ligament. These findings are consistent with a symptomatic inguinal hernia, which can lead to complications if left untreated. The preferred management of a patient with a symptomatic inguinal hernia is elective surgical repair to prevent potential complications and to alleviate symptoms.

Depending on the patient's risk and clinical presentation, inguinal hernias can be managed with watchful waiting, elective, urgent, or emergent surgical repair.
 
  • Watchful waiting is indicated for the management of inguinal hernias in asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic patients with a low risk of complications. 
  • Elective surgical repair is indicated for the management of inguinal hernias in symptomatic patients to prevent potential complications and alleviate symptoms. If the patient experiences worsening pain or inability to reduce the hernia, urgent surgical repair may be warranted. 
  • Urgent surgical repair is indicated for the management of incarcerated inguinal hernias in the absence of bowel compromise. If the hernia is chronically incarcerated, hernia reduction can be attempted prior to surgical repair. 
  • Emergent surgical repair is indicated for the management of strangulated inguinal hernias, where blood supply to the herniated bowel segment is compromised, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Elective surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Emergent surgical repair:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical repair is indicated for the management of a strangulated inguinal hernia. This patient presents with a symptomatic reducible inguinal hernia without signs of bowel ischemia and necrosis, making elective surgical repair the preferred management.  
❌ Urgent surgical repair within 48 hours:
Incorrect: Urgent surgical repair is not indicated, as there are no signs of complications warranting urgent intervention. The patient has a symptomatic reducible, non-tender inguinal hernia, making elective surgical repair the preferred management.  
❌ Abdominal binder:
Incorrect: An abdominal binder may provide temporary relief of symptoms, but it does not resolve the underlying hernia. Elective surgical repair is indicated to prevent incarceration and provide definitive treatment.  
❌ Reassurance and observation:
Incorrect: While this approach may be indicated for the management of a small asymptomatic inguinal hernia, it is not the best next step in the management of a symptomatic inguinal hernia. Elective surgical repair is the preferred option to prevent potential complications and provide long-term symptom relief.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after undergoing an uncomplicated ventral hernia repair with mesh. On post-op day 2 the patient feels short of breath and is having incisional site pain. She has had a bowel movement and is passing gas. She does not have chest pain, nausea, vomiting, urinary urgency or dysuria. Her medical history is significant for a 30 pack-year smoking history, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 100.6°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 140/82 mmHg, pulse is 98/minute, respiratory rate is 22/minute, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On pulmonary examination, the patient has increased work of breathing, crackles in the lung bases bilaterally and dullness to percussion. There is no significant abdominal tenderness, erythema, edema or purulent drainage around the incision site. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is 2 days out from ventral hernia repair with mesh and presents with difficulty breathing, fever, and crackles in bilateral lung bases, suggestive of atelectasis–a common cause of postoperative fever within the first 2 days following surgery. Risk factors for atelectasis include incisional pain, shallow breathing with poor alveolar recruitment, depressed cough from narcotics, prolonged bed rest, and smoking history.

Postoperative fever is defined as a systemic body temperature that is at or above 38°C or 100.4°F within the postoperative period which gets divided into 4 phases based on the timing of the fever: immediate, acute, subacute, and delayed.

An immediate postoperative fever occurs within 24 hours of the procedure. The most common cause is physiologic, but life-threatening complications such as acute transfusion reactions or adverse drug reactions can also occur. Physiologic fevers are transient, self-limited, and tend to occur following surgeries involving high levels of tissue trauma. Acute transfusion reactions should be suspected in patients who received blood products or have a personal or family history of transfusion reactions. Physical exam findings include flushing, skin rash, angioedema, respiratory distress, or hypotension. An adverse drug reaction can occur if the patient receives anesthetics, antibiotics, or other medications.

The acute phase of postoperative fever occurs between postoperative days 1 to 7. The causes of fever during this time are recalled using the 5 Ws:  

  •  Wind - Atelectasis or Pneumonia 
  •  Water - Urinary Tract Infection 
  •  Wound - Surgical Site Infection - superficial and deep 
  •  Walking - Vascular causes - DVT, phlebitis, central line infection 
  •  Wonder Drugs - Drug Fever

 
Subacute postoperative fever occurs between weeks 1-4 post-procedure. There are 2 important diagnoses that should not be missed during this time: anastomotic leaks and clostridium difficile infection. In an anastomotic leak, patients will present with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or obstipation after abdominal surgery. Physical exam will reveal abdominal tenderness, distension, and signs of peritonitis (such as rebound, guarding, and decreased bowel sounds). The use of antibiotics increases the risk of Clostridium Difficile infection. Patients will complain of colicky abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, nausea, abdominal tenderness, and distension.

Lastly, the delayed phase of postoperative fever occurs more than 30 days after the procedure. Most fevers that occur at this stage are unrelated to the surgery and caused by community infections such as upper respiratory infections. However, device or prosthesis infections and fistula formation are two complications that should not be missed. A device or prosthesis infection should be considered when there is intraoperative device implantation (such as mesh during hernia repair, ICD) or prosthesis implantation during joint replacement surgery. Patients will present with erythema, edema, and tenderness around the implantation site. Fistulas may occur in patients that have undergone resections requiring anastomosis or postoperative chemoradiation. They often present with erythema, tenderness, foul discharge, or bleeding from a visible fistula site.  

Option Analysis

✅ Atelectasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acute transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Acute transfusion reactions present within the first 24 hours after surgery with the transfusion of blood products. This patient does not have a history of receiving a blood transfusion and is two days post-op.  
❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Urinary tract infections usually present between postoperative days 3 to 5, with urinary frequency, urgency, and lower abdominal pain or pressure. This patient has none of these symptoms. Patients with indwelling foley catheters are at increased risk for UTIs.  
❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: Surgical site infections usually present between postoperative days 5 to 7 with incisional pain. Physical exam often demonstrates erythema, edema, purulent drainage, a fluctuant mass, and tenderness to palpation at the incision site.  
❌ Clostridium difficile infection:
Incorrect: Clostridium difficile infections typically present between weeks 1 to 4 post-op. Patients present with abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, nausea, and a history of antibiotic use.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital on postoperative day 7 for evaluation of drainage from her cesarean section incision site. Her postoperative course was complicated by a superficial surgical site infection treated with antibiotics. She was discharged on postoperative day 4 and her staples were removed on the day of discharge. She has been having pink-tinged drainage from the site of the incision since discharge. She has mild nausea, but no vomiting. She has been passing gas and had a bowel movement today. She has a medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, type 2. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 98/minute, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. On abdominal examination, there is mild erythema around the site of her incision with large amounts of salmon-colored drainage and partial separation of the wound. There is mild tenderness to palpation around the incision and no palpable mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of serosanguinous (‘salmon-colored’) discharge from a recent surgical incision site and partial separation of the incision consistent with wound dehiscence. Her recent abdominal surgery that was complicated by a surgical site infection along with her history of diabetes mellitus puts her at risk for postoperative wound complications.  

Postoperative wound complications can be categorized as wound disruptions, abnormal communications, or wound infections. Wound disruptions are conditions that directly affect the integrity of the incision site and include dehiscence, evisceration, or fluid collections. Abnormal communications refer to fistulas which are direct communications between two epithelial-lined spaces. Lastly, wound infections refer to superficial surgical site infections, deep surgical site infections, organ/space infections, or abscesses. A thorough history and physical examination can help to differentiate between these wound complications.



Patients with wound disruptions may present after straining or lifting weight causing mechanical strain, and they may report a popping sensation. Factors that increase the risk of wound disruptions include smoking, diabetes, malnutrition, and prior radiation. With dehiscence, there is separation of the wound but bowel contents are still contained. In an evisceration, there is separation of the wound with herniation of abdominal contents. It is important to identify dehiscence early on and to intervene before it progresses to evisceration, which is a surgical emergency.

Option Analysis

✅ Fascial (wound) dehiscence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abdominal wall hematoma:
Incorrect: A hematoma is a blood collection that occurs secondary to bleeding inside the muscle layers. On examination, palpation of a localized, non-pulsatile mass can be appreciated with bloody drainage, whereas this patient has serosanguinous drainage.
❌ Ventral incisional hernia:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with large amounts of drainage of serosanguinous fluid. While she is at risk for developing a hernia, the presentation would reveal findings of a protrusion of the abdominal wall or bulge.
❌ Seroma:
Incorrect: A seroma is an accumulation of serous fluid that can occur following abdominal surgery. Physical examination would reveal a soft, swollen lump with clear drainage.
❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with serosanguinous discharge from her incisional site. The presence of purulent drainage and surrounding erythema would better support the diagnosis of surgical site infection.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain and fever 5 days after a hemicolectomy that was performed to remove an ascending colonic mass. The fever started on postoperative day 2 and was associated with progressively worsening abdominal pain most pronounced in the right lower quadrant. He rates the abdominal pain as an 8/10. He has nausea but no vomiting and has not had a bowel movement since his surgery. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 107/minute, blood pressure is 118/78, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. The incision is clean, dry, and intact with no palpable fluctuance or erythema. Decreased bowel sounds are heard and there is tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Labs are significant for a white blood cell count of 16K, elevated ESR, and CRP. Which of the following should be ordered next?

choices.text: CT abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast

questions.solution:
The patient presents with findings consistent with an organ/space surgical site infection. He has fever, tachycardia, and tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without any accompanying skin findings (such as erythema, drainage, or wound breakdown) or signs of peritonitis. Patients with organ/space surgical site infections usually present with fever, malaise, and pain in the region where the surgery was performed. They can also occur as complications of progressive deep incisional surgical site infections, with accompanying skin findings present. Identification of an organ/space surgical site infection is made after imaging confirms the presence of an abscess and wound culture (obtained either percutaneously or surgically) confirms the infection.  

In patients that are presenting with signs and symptoms of an infectious postoperative wound complication, after initial history and physical examination, further evaluation with laboratory tests and imaging should be done. These can include CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP, albumin, wound cultures, and blood cultures. The laboratory evaluation will show findings of leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP with positive cultures in a patient who has a deep surgical site or organ/space infection. Further evaluation with ultrasound or CT scan will confirm findings to support a deep surgical site infection or organ/space infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis is preferred in patients with suspected organ/space infection as it provides a more detailed view of the underlying tissue and organ space. Findings on imaging can include fluid collections, surrounding edema, soft tissue stranding, cobblestoning, or the presence of an abscess.

Option Analysis

✅ CT abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abdominal radiography:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with abdominal pain, fever, and signs of obstruction. Abdominal radiography could show an obstruction; however, in this patient who also has signs of possible organ/space surgical site infection, a CT scan would be more appropriate for further evaluation.
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms suggestive of an infection and will likely need antibiotic treatment. However, further investigation to identify the source of the infection should be done in this stable patient without signs of peritonitis prior to initiating treatment with antibiotics.
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of an organ/space surgical site infection. He is stable and is not presenting with an acute abdomen, and therefore imaging can be done to assess the need for surgical intervention.
❌ NG tube placement:
Incorrect: This patient may need an NG tube for the SBO; however, given accompanying signs of organ space infection, further investigation with imaging to further delineate the diagnosis and management should be done before treatment with an NG tube.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain. The patient had a partial colectomy performed one week ago due to diverticulitis complicated by abscess formation. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and obesity. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F), pulse is 120/min, blood pressure is 95/65 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable and is moaning. Abdominal examination shows abdominal distension, rigidity, guarding and rebound tenderness. The patient is given intravenous fluids and analgesics, and several laboratory studies are obtained and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Consult general surgery for emergent exploratory laparotomy
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of postoperative abdominal pain seven days following a partial colectomy.  He has evidence of peritonitis on physical examination. Given the peritonitis and the patient’s ill appearance, the next best step in management is an emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy.

Abdominal pain is commonly reported by patients after surgery. There are many causes, some even life-threatening, but they can be grouped into three categories: disruption of normal healing, infection, or other benign physiologic processes. Abdominal pain can be superficial, or limited to the abdominal wall; or it can be deep, involving organ spaces.

The acute management for patients presenting with postoperative abdominal pain involves the rapid assessment of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients with evidence of airway compromise or significant vital sign derangements should receive the appropriate stabilizing interventions (e.g. endotracheal intubation) prior to further evaluation. Stable patients should have a full history obtained and a thorough physical examination. Patients should be evaluated for evidence of peritonitis, which includes a severely distended and rigid abdomen, diffuse tenderness, rebound pain and guarding, as well as associated tachycardia and hypotension. Patients with peritonitis, like the one in this case, often have a significant intra-abdominal process like perforation, anastomotic leak, intra-abdominal bleeding or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. These patients require surgical consultation for emergent laparotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Consult general surgery for emergent exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and should have emergent surgical consultation prior to CT imaging. This patient will likely require immediate operative intervention.
❌ Order ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect:  This patient has evidence of peritonitis, a transabdominal ultrasound is unlikely to be diagnostic for this patient. Given this presentation, the next best step in management is emergent surgical consultation.
❌ Administer IV piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics should be a component of therapy for this patient who presents with peritonitis; however, vancomycin is probably unnecessary and surgical consultation takes precedence over administering antibiotics.
❌ Place a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis; while this may be secondary to a bowel obstruction (which would require a nasogastric tube), this patient should have emergent surgical consultation first.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right flank pain. The patient underwent an outpatient percutaneous kidney biopsy two days ago, and the flank pain developed 24 hours after the procedure. The pain has progressively worsened. Medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg. The incision site on the right flank is clean and dry. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a dense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region. Which of the following physical examination findings may be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region
Arrest of inspiration with palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant
Decreased pulse intensity in the right femoral artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right flank pain in the setting of a recent right kidney biopsy. Imaging shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region. Signs, symptoms, history, and imaging are consistent with an iatrogenic right retroperitoneal hematoma.

History is important for determining the cause of a retroperitoneal hematoma which can be traumatic, non-traumatic, or iatrogenic. Patients can present with abdominal, flank, back, and groin pain. Low hemoglobin and hypotension can be seen. Patients with hemodynamic instability should be stabilized first before further evaluation.
 

Several physical examination findings may be seen in the setting of a retroperitoneal hematoma. These include the Grey-Turner, Fox, and Bryant signs. The Grey-Turner sign refers to flank ecchymosis on the side of the retroperitoneal hematoma. The Fox sign refers to inguinal ecchymosis. Finally, the Bryant sign refers to scrotal ecchymosis. Although these signs may be suggestive of a retroperitoneal bleed, they are not always evident as it can takes days for them to appear. In cases of iatrogenic causes, the abdominal examination may reveal the incision sites from percutaneous surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region:
Incorrect: Groin pain and groin ecchymosis can be seen with retroperitoneal hematomas, however suprapubic tenderness, which is typically a sign of acute cystitis, would not be expected. The presence of a hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region after recent kidney biopsy is consistent with a retroperitoneal hematoma.  
❌ Arrest of inspiration with palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant:
Incorrect: This finding describes a positive Murphy sign, which can be seen with acute cholecystitis. This patient’s recent kidney biopsy and hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region is consistent with a retroperitoneal hematoma.  
❌ Tympanic sounds with abdominal percussion:
Incorrect: In patients with small bowel obstruction, percussion of the abdomen may produce tympanic bowel sounds due to gaseous distention of the small bowel loops. Imaging will typically reveal multiple dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and a transition point. This patient’s findings are consistent with a right retroperitoneal hematoma.
❌ Decreased pulse intensity in the right femoral artery:
Incorrect: Theoretically, a large retroperitoneal hematoma can displace and compress the intra-abdominal and intrapelvic vasculature, resulting in reduced pulse intensity in the femoral arteries. However, this finding is exceedingly rare and would be less likely than Grey’s sign (flank ecchymosis).  
✅ Ecchymosis over the right flank:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is undergoing a preoperative evaluation for an appendectomy. The patient has type 1 diabetes mellitus and has never had any surgeries. The patient’s only prescribed medication is insulin. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.  Which of the following medical history elements, if present, may be a contraindication to isoflurane administration?
questions.solution:
Isoflurane is a volatile anesthetic used for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. One of its most notable adverse reactions is malignant hyperthermia. Other medications which may trigger malignant hyperthermia include desflurane, sevoflurane, and succinylcholine.

Malignant hyperthermia is an anesthetic complication with a high mortality rate if not promptly treated. Certain anesthetics can trigger excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in genetically-sensitive individuals. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

When evaluating patients before anesthesia induction, assessing their risk factors for complications, such as malignant hyperthermia, is important. A personal or family history of malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication to anesthetics known to trigger the condition. Remember, a negative personal or family history of malignant hyperthermia does not rule out the potential for it. When assessing preoperative patients it is important to be aware of their home and perioperative medication lists, as certain medications (e.g., beta-blockers, sedatives, neuromuscular blocking agents) may mask clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Recent elevated HgbA1c:
Incorrect: Poor glucose control is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
❌ Over-the-counter medication use:
Incorrect: While assessing potential drug interactions is essential, over-the-counter medications are less likely to be a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
✅ Family history of anesthetic reactions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Tobacco use is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
❌ Recent insulin administration:
Incorrect: Tight perioperative glucose control is essential but is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of uterine fibroids is admitted on post-op day 3 following a total abdominal hysterectomy. She has been experiencing subjective fevers and lower abdominal pain. She received routine anesthesia and required transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells for intraoperative blood loss. A urinary catheter was placed during the procedure and removed, however, due to difficulty voiding, the urinary catheter was replaced and remains in place. She has had two bowel movements since her procedure. She does not have chest pain, difficulty breathing, or a cough. Temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C), pulse is 102/minute, blood pressure is 136/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, she has a normal cardio-pulmonary examination. On abdominal examination, the incision sites appear to be healing well without erythema or purulent drainage. She has normal bowel sounds and her abdomen is soft to palpation. There is suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Which of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a fever and lower abdominal pain 3 days after total abdominal hysterectomy in the acute postoperative period. She has an indwelling foley catheter. Her symptoms and physical examination finding of suprapubic tenderness suggest the presence of a urinary tract infection. Based on her history, physical exam findings, and the most likely source of infection she should have a CBC, complete metabolic panel, urinalysis, blood and urine cultures sent.

Urinalysis can confirm the diagnosis of a urinary tract infection with findings of nitrates, leukocyte esterase, high WBCs, and bacteriuria. In a patient suspected of having a UTI, a urine culture should also be obtained to ensure appropriate antibiotic selection.

A postoperative fever is defined as a systemic body temperature that is at or above 38°C or 100.4°F in the postoperative period. Fever workup in patients presenting with postoperative fever often includes the following tests: complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, urinalysis, chest radiography, and blood cultures. The specific workup should be tailored to the patient’s signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings. Knowing the details of the surgery (ie, prosthetic implant) and the postoperative day can also provide clues to the likely source of the fever.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Troponin:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with lower abdominal pain and fever after a recent procedure. Troponin is a cardiac enzyme ordered in patients to work up cardiac ischemia. This patient is not experiencing chest pain.  
❌ Coombs test:
Incorrect: The Coombs test is a diagnostic test to check for antibodies against red blood cells. If a patient presents with fever in the immediate postoperative period and has history of blood transfusion, Coombs test should be ordered to evaluate for an acute transfusion reaction. This patient has an acute, not immediate post-op fever that occurred on POD 3.  
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: Patients presenting with fever in the acute postoperative period may have respiratory causes such as atelectasis or pneumonia. This patient is not experiencing respiratory symptoms and has a normal pulmonary examination.  
❌ D-dimer:
Incorrect: Patients are at increased risk of developing venous thrombosis, such as pulmonary embolism after a procedure. This patient is not experiencing respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath, or cough and has a normal oxygen saturation, which makes pulmonary embolism less likely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain. Five days ago the patient underwent open partial colectomy with anastomosis to treat colonic adenocarcinoma. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and ulcerative colitis. At home, the patient has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and subjective fevers. The patient is passing gas and had a bowel movement yesterday. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 95/65 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. The abdomen is distended and rigid with rebound, tenderness, and guarding. General surgery is consulted and laboratory studies are obtained and pending. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on abdominal imaging?

choices.text: Free intraabdominal air and fluid and extravasation of contrast around the anastomosis site
Transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel
Intraabdominal fluid collection or phlegmon near the operative site
Increasing air under the diaphragm with serial imaging
Diffusely distended loops of bowel without a transition point

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of postoperative abdominal pain. He has evidence of peritonitis and an acute abdomen, and given the recent surgical history, this is most likely due to an anastomotic leak. This complication will appear on CT imaging as free intraabdominal air and fluid, and extravasation of contrast around the site of the anastomosis.

CT and ultrasound imaging can help differentiate between the many causes of postoperative abdominal pain. Superficial causes of postoperative abdominal pain include fascial dehiscence which will be seen on CT or ultrasound as separation of the fascial layers. Seromas or hematomas will be readily identifiable on ultrasonography, as will superficial surgical site infections. Patients may also present with deep organ space complications of abdominal surgery for which CT imaging is required. Patients with bowel obstruction will have a transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel on CT imaging. Patients with a phlegmon or abscess will have an intraabdominal fluid collection near the operative site on CT imaging. Patients who have had laparoscopic surgery and have increasing air seen under the diaphragm with serial imaging, likely have pneumoperitoneum.

Option Analysis

✅ Free intraabdominal air and fluid and extravasation of contrast around the anastomosis site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of a closed-loop bowel obstruction which more commonly presents with absent bowel sounds and decreased bowel movements. This patient is passing gas.
❌ Intraabdominal fluid collection or phlegmon near the operative site:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of a deep surgical site infection which includes abscess formation. However, given this patient’s recent anastomosis and physical exam findings, he will more likely have imaging findings consistent with an anastomotic leak.
❌ Increasing air under the diaphragm with serial imaging:
Incorrect: Increasing air under the diaphragm is more commonly seen with pneumoperitoneum which is a complication of laparoscopic surgery. It typically is seen in the immediate postoperative period and not this far out from surgery.
❌ Diffusely distended loops of bowel without a transition point:
Incorrect: This finding is commonly seen in patients with postoperative ileus. These patients have obstipation and cannot tolerate oral intake after abdominal surgery. They typically have normal vital signs without fever and hypotension.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a penetrating trauma. The patient was walking home last night when he was attacked from behind and stabbed. The patient is currently experiencing excruciating pain in the left flank. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 89/56 mmHg. Physical examination shows two stab wounds in the left flank with surrounding ecchymoses. Fresh blood is flowing out from the stab sites. Serum hemoglobin is 10.8 g/dL. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Obtain contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Measure coagulation parameters, including PT, PTT, and INR

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe left flank pain and hemodynamic instability after being stabbed in the left flank. These findings are concerning for a retroperitoneal hematoma that may have developed from the accumulation of blood in the retroperitoneal space.

When assessing a patient with signs and symptoms suggestive of a retroperitoneal hematoma, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is hemodynamically stable. If the patient is unstable, the next steps are to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. This may include establishing IV access, administering IV fluids, and potentially intubating the patient. In addition, blood typing and crossmatching should be performed in case there is need for blood transfusions.

After stabilization, a focused history and physical examination should be obtained. If the patient is conscious, they may report abdominal, flank, or back pain; dizziness; or syncope. They may have a history of blunt or penetrating trauma or a recent endovascular procedure. Physical examination may reveal tachycardia and hypotension as well as possible pallor and visible traumatic injuries.

If there is a high suspicion for retroperitoneal hematoma, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast should be obtained once the patient is stabilized. Imaging may sometimes show additional traumatic injuries, such as a pelvic fracture or kidney injury; but the key finding is a complex fluid collection in the retroperitoneal space.

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient was stabbed in the left flank and is now presenting with hemodynamic instability. The first step in management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Afterward, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be obtained to evaluate for the underlying etiology.  
✅ Administer intravenous saline bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Measure coagulation parameters, including PT, PTT, and INR:
Incorrect: This patient was stabbed in the left flank and is now presenting with hemodynamic instability. The first step in management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Afterward, coagulation parameters can be obtained, especially if the patient has a history of coagulopathy or is on any anticoagulants.  
❌ Perform emergent angioembolization:
Incorrect: Without imaging, it remains unclear if the underlying etiology can be successfully treated via embolization. For instance, if the stab wounds lead to transection of the renal artery or vein, then the condition would be better managed by emergent laparotomy (rather than angioembolization).  
❌ Evaluate for inguinal ecchymosis:
Incorrect: Inguinal ecchymosis can be seen in the setting of retroperitoneal hematoma. This physical examination finding is termed the Fox sign. This patient is hemodynamically unstable. The patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation should be first stabilized before examining for this physical examination sign.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right groin pain and a tender, non-reducible bulge. The bulge has been present for several years but has progressively increased in size over the past several weeks. He has not had any nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient appears diaphoretic and uncomfortable. Abdominal examination is significant for a non-reducible, tender, erythematous mass in the right groin above the inguinal ligament. Intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics are administered. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates leukocytosis and elevated lactate. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Abdominal CT scan with IV contrast
Admission to the critical care unit for observation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe right groin pain, a tender non-reducible hernia, and hemodynamic instability. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of a strangulated inguinal hernia and associated sepsis. In addition to medical stabilization, the best next step in management involves emergent surgical repair.

A strangulated inguinal hernia occurs when blood supply to the herniated bowel segment is compromised due to external pressure applied by the hernia sac and the surrounding tissue, leading to ischemia. Patients with strangulated inguinal hernias often present with a non-reducible tender erythematous bulge in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament. They may have signs of sepsis, hemodynamic instability, and possibly bowel obstruction. The management of a strangulated inguinal hernia includes prompt recognition, resuscitation with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and immediate surgical correction. Timely surgical intervention is essential to prevent complications such as bowel perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis, which can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. There should be no attempt to reduce the hernia into the abdominal cavity, as the hernia may contain necrotic bowel tissue.  

Option Analysis

✅ Immediate surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Manual reduction of the hernia:
Incorrect: Reducing a strangulated hernia can lead to peritonitis and sepsis and is therefore contraindicated.  
❌ Abdominal CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: Although a CT scan can help confirm the diagnosis, it should not delay definitive surgical intervention for this patient with signs of strangulation.  
❌ Urgent surgical intervention within 48 hours:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings suggestive of a strangulated inguinal hernia requiring emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Admission to the critical care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical repair is necessary to address the underlying cause of the patient's condition and to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with right lower quadrant cramping abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 8 hours. She has been unable to pass gas or have a bowel movement for the past 24 hours. She has not had fevers, diarrhea, or blood in the stool. Past medical history is significant for an open appendectomy 30 years ago. BMI is 34 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination bowel sounds are high-pitched and hyperactive. Abdominal exam reveals a distended abdomen and a tender bulge in the right inguinal region that cannot be reduced. Abdominal x-ray reveals distended bowel loops with air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset cramping abdominal pain, vomiting, and distended bowel loops with air-fluid levels on abdominal imaging, suggestive of small bowel obstruction (SBO). The presence of a tender bulge in the right inguinal region that cannot be reduced on physical exam, suggests an incarcerated inguinal hernia as the cause of the SBO. When inguinal hernias become incarcerated the hernia contents (small or large bowel) become trapped in the hernia sac, where reduced venous and lymphatic flow leads to swelling of the incarcerated tissue.

Inguinal hernias occur when a portion of the intestine protrudes through a weakness or defect in the abdominal wall in the inguinal region. They can present in four ways: asymptomatic, symptomatic, incarcerated, or strangulated. Patients with an asymptomatic inguinal hernias typically present with an incidentally found reducible mass or lump in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament that may enlarge with increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during standing, coughing, or straining. These patients can be managed with watchful waiting. When patients develop discomfort or pain in the inguinal region, especially with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, lifting heavy objects), they are classified as having a symptomatic inguinal hernia. These patients require elective surgical repair.

Patients with an incarcerated inguinal hernias present with non-reducible masses or bulges in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament in the absence of signs and symptoms related to bowel ischemia. These patients may develop small bowel obstruction and present with nausea, vomiting, and the absence of bowel movements. Management consists of urgent surgical repair to prevent bowel ischemia and necrosis.

A strangulated inguinal hernia is a surgical emergency associated with bowel ischemia and necrosis. Patients with a strangulated inguinal hernia typically present with a non-reducible, tender, and erythematous bulge in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament along with signs and symptoms of bowel ischemia including pain, fever, and possibly small bowel obstruction. These patients should be treated immediately with IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, NG tube for decompression, and emergent surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Incarcerated inguinal hernia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesions from previous abdominal surgery:
Incorrect: Although adhesions from previous surgeries can lead to bowel obstruction, the presence of a tender bulge that cannot be reduced in the groin makes an incarcerated inguinal hernia complicated by small bowel obstruction more likely.  
❌ Volvulus:
Incorrect: A volvulus may present with obstructive symptoms and typically appears as a dilated, inverted, U-shaped loop of the colon on abdominal imaging. The presence of a tender bulge in the right inguinal region makes an incarcerated inguinal hernia a more likely cause of this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Groin hematoma:
Incorrect: Although a groin hematoma may appear as swelling in the inguinal area on physical examination, it rarely causes small bowel obstruction and is usually associated with a history of trauma, or anticoagulation use.  
❌ Small bowel stricture:
Incorrect: A small bowel stricture could cause bowel obstruction; however, it is usually associated with a history of Crohn’s disease. The patient's history of right lower quadrant discomfort and the presence of a bulge in the inguinal region are more suggestive of an incarcerated inguinal hernia complicated by SBO.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a left total knee replacement, and sevoflurane is used to maintain anesthesia. Forty-five minutes into the procedure, the patient starts over-breathing the ventilator. Temperature is 39.1 °C (102.3 °F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 136/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On examination, the patient is diaphoretic, and the muscles are rigid. End-tidal CO2 is elevated. The procedure is stopped, dantrolene is given, and cooling measures are initiated. The ventilator settings are adjusted to assist in hyperventilation. An ECG is obtained, showing  normal sinus rhythm, peaked T-waves, and QRS complex widening. Laboratory studies are listed below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s hyperthermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypercarbia, and muscle rigidity during anesthesia are concerning for malignant hyperthermia.

Prompt recognition and management of malignant hyperthermia is essential to prevent mortality. Once suspected, acute management consists of administering dantrolene and discontinuing the offending anesthetic (in this case, sevoflurane). Hyperventilation should be attempted to remove excess CO2. Cooling measures should be started if the patient’s core temperature is above 39.0 °C.

An ECG is typically performed due to the risk of hyperkalemia and deadly arrhythmia in malignant hyperthermia. In this case, it reveals peaked T waves and widening of the QRS complexes. Coupled with a potassium level of 7.0 mEq/L, the patient is at high risk for developing a ventricular arrhythmia or asystole. Thus, prompt treatment of hyperkalemia is warranted. IV calcium should be given to stabilize the myocardium. Next, measures are implemented to shift potassium into cells, such as IV insulin, albuterol, and sodium bicarbonate.

Additional management of malignant hyperthermia may involve IV fluids to prevent kidney injury related to rhabdomyolysis and sodium bicarbonate for severe metabolic acidosis. Patients should be monitored closely in an ICU setting for at least 24 hours, where maintenance doses of dantrolene can be given.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV calcium gluconate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Ventricular arrhythmias would be a concern due to the patient’s severe hyperkalemia. However, this patient’s ECG does not demonstrate ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia, so defibrillation would not be appropriate.  
❌ Administer IV fluids:
Incorrect: IV fluid administration is essential for preventing pigment-induced nephropathy from rhabdomyolysis. However, the ECG manifestations of severe hyperkalemia are potentially life-threatening and should be addressed first.  
❌ Administer lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines may be used to manage muscle rigidity in neuroleptic malignant syndrome. However, this patient’s history, examination, and studies are more consistent with malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ Administer IV magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate may be used for torsades de pointes. However, the patient’s ECG shows signs of hyperkalemia and does not show torsades de pointes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is postoperative day 7 following exploratory laparotomy for a gunshot wound to the abdomen which required small bowel resection and reanastomosis. He has been having persistent fevers and worsening abdominal pain for 4 days. His last bowel movement occurred on postoperative day 5 and he has not passed gas in 24 hours. He has no prior medical history. His current medications include IV morphine, IV ceftriaxone, and metronidazole. Temperature is 101.2°F (38.4°C), pulse is 112/minute, blood pressure is 125/82 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/minute. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in pain. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is distended with decreased bowel sounds; there is no significant erythema, edema, or purulent drainage from the incision site. There is diffuse moderate tenderness to palpation, rebound, and guarding. White blood cell count is 18,500/mm<sup>3</sup>. CMP reveals low magnesium and potassium. Urinalysis and chest radiography are unremarkable. Blood and urine cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with PO and IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with an acute abdomen and peritonitis on postoperative day 7 following an exploratory laparotomy with small bowel resection and reanastomosis. An initial postoperative fever workup was initiated. Additional diagnostic testing is needed to evaluate for a source of infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast (oral and IV) should be obtained to evaluate for a deep surgical site infection such as an abscess or anastomotic leak. PO contrast delineates the bowel lumen and extravasation of the contrast can be seen in the case of an anastomotic leak. IV contrast helps define the walls of an abscess if one is present.

The evaluation of patients with postoperative fever should be guided by the patient’s signs, symptoms, physical examination, and most likely cause based on their surgery and postoperative period. Ultrasound can be performed to evaluate for superficial or vascular processes like phlebitis. Ultrasound of the surgical site can identify superficial abscesses by demonstrating soft tissue edema or fluid collections. Venous ultrasound can identify venous thrombosis. Blood, urine, sputum, and wound cultures can be performed based on the individual patient’s presentation. Stool cultures to rule out C. difficile should be sent in patients presenting with diarrhea and colicky abdominal pain.

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with PO and IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for a deep-space infectious process such as an anastomotic leak or abscess. An ultrasound would be appropriate for evaluation of a superficial infection.  
❌ Additional antibiotic coverage:
Incorrect: This patient has been having persistent fevers despite empiric antibiotic therapy. Extending coverage may be indicated, but further imaging with CT should be performed to better characterize the underlying process.  
❌ Surgical exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: Surgery may be indicated in this patient but should be guided by additional imaging to identify the underlying process and the appropriate treatment.  
❌ NG tube placement:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of bowel obstruction with constipation and rebound and guarding on physical examination. Placement of an NG tube may be indicated for decompression; however, the most appropriate initial step is to order a CT of the abdomen and pelvis for further characterization of a suspected intra-abdominal process.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of fever 5 days postoperatively after having total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingectomy, and oophorectomy. Fevers started 3 days post-surgery and she is currently on clindamycin and metronidazole. She also has diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 126/minute, blood pressure is 82/48 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24/minute, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient is uncomfortable, pale and diaphoretic. Cardiac examination is unremarkable and the lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Her surgical incision sites are clean, dry, and intact. There is no surrounding erythema or discharge from the incision site. The abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation with rebound and guarding. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of peritonitis and sepsis in the setting of recent abdominal surgery. In patients presenting with signs of an acute postoperative complication, the first step is to evaluate for stability. If the patient is unstable, the airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. This may involve intubating the patient, obtaining IV access, or administering IV fluids before proceeding with the rest of the assessment.  

Patients with recent abdominal surgery are at increased risk for developing sepsis secondary to peritonitis which can be life-threatening and surgery should be consulted for possible exploratory laparotomy for diagnosis and treatment. Once the patient has been stabilized, additional evaluation with laboratory tests including CBC, CMP, blood cultures, wound cultures, and possibly imaging can be done. The patient can also be started on supportive care including pain management, wound care (if indicated), and NPO status. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated with appropriate tailoring once culture results are available.

Option Analysis

✅ IV fluid administration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Broadening of antibiotic therapy:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with sepsis and findings consistent with peritonitis in the setting of recent abdominal surgery. Expanding the coverage of her antibiotic regimen should be considered, but the initial priority should be to stabilize her with fluid resuscitation.
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with sepsis and peritonitis in the setting of recent surgery. Surgery should be consulted as they may perform exploratory laparotomy for diagnosis and treatment. Imaging with CT scan may not be performed for diagnosis.
❌ Wound exploration:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs of sepsis with examination findings consistent with peritonitis. She does not have signs of a superficial surgical site infection (such as erythema, fluctuance, or drainage), though a deep infection or organ space infection cannot be excluded. The priority should be IV fluid resuscitation.
❌ Emergent surgery:
Incorrect: The patient is presenting with signs of sepsis with findings consistent with peritonitis. Further evaluation and treatment for the underlying etiology needs to be done, which likely requires exploratory laparotomy. However, the patient should first be stabilized before surgery.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient had an uncomplicated hysterectomy six days ago for the treatment of uterine fibroids. The patient was lifting a box yesterday and immediately felt a “pop” in the lower abdomen. The patient has been having bowel movements and passing gas normally.  There are no associated fever, chills, nausea or vomiting. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7 °F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows separation of the wound edges overlying the pubic incision. Which of the following additional examination findings is most likely to be present with this post surgical complication?

choices.text: Bulge at the incision site with Valsalva maneuver
Palpable well-circumscribed mass around the surgical site
Erythema, mild induration and tenderness around the incision
Distention, diffuse tenderness, and rebound pain in the abdomen

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of postoperative abdominal pain with history and findings on examination that are suggestive of fascial dehiscence. Patients with fascial dehiscence can present with a bulge at the incision with Valsalva maneuvers, and serosanguinous discharge.



Abdominal pain is commonly reported by patients after surgery. There are many causes, some even life-threatening. Causes of postoperative abdominal pain can be grouped into three categories: disruption of normal healing, infection, or other benign physiologic processes. Abdominal pain can be superficial and limited to the abdominal wall or it can be deep with involvement of organ spaces.

Several clinical as well as historical features can assist in the differentiation of acute life-threatening postoperative abdominal pain. Patients with a severely distended and rigid abdomen, diffuse tenderness, rebound pain, guarding, and tachycardia and tachypnea or signs of sepsis should undergo emergent surgical evaluation and likely exploratory laparotomy. These patients are more likely to have a deep organ space process like an anastomotic leak, intra-abdominal abscess, or viscus perforation.

Patients with superficial postoperative abdominal pain are typically well-appearing and may have normal vital signs. Specific findings that may suggest a particular diagnosis include erythema, mild induration, and tenderness around the incision with a superficial surgical incision infection. An enlarging mass around the surgical site may suggest a hematoma or seroma. Patients with fascial dehiscence will have separation of the wound edges caused by abdominal tension overcoming tissue or suture strength. With fascial dehiscence patients may report a “popping” sensation with heavy lifting, serosanguinous fluid drainage may be seen, and there may be a bulge at the site when physical maneuvers (e.g. heavy lifting) are performed. Patients with complete dehiscence are at risk for evisceration of bowel contents.

Option Analysis

✅ Bulge at the incision site with Valsalva maneuver:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Palpable well-circumscribed mass around the surgical site:
Incorrect: This finding is more consistent with a seroma or hematoma as opposed to complete fascial dehiscence.
❌ Erythema, mild induration and tenderness around the incision:
Incorrect: This finding is more consistent with a superficial surgical site infection.
❌ Distention, diffuse tenderness, and rebound pain in the abdomen:
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of peritonitis from a deep space surgical process like anastomotic leak, intra-abdominal abscess, or perforation.
❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: An absent cremasteric reflex is commonly associated with testicular torsion. This clinical exam finding is not related to complete fascial dehiscence and would not be present in a woman.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation after being involved in a motorcycle accident. EMS reports the patient hit a curb at high speed and flew over the handlebars. The patient was wearing a helmet, and a cervical collar was placed in the field. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 36°C (96.5°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 177/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient appears anxious but can state his name and speak in clear full sentences. The patient states he has pelvic discomfort. He is moving all extremities spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally. There are breath sounds bilaterally and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. GCS is 14 with one point subtracted due to mild confusion. IV access is established. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Remove all clothing from the patient
Roll the patient and examine the back
Administer one unit of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trauma in the setting of a motorcycle accident. The initial trauma screening examination, or the primary survey has been started. The patient has had all major components of the exam performed thus far, except for exposure. Exposure involves removing all the patient's clothing to expose the skin and evaluate for injuries.

Trauma is one of the major causes of mortality and morbidity worldwide, and a standardized approach to trauma, known as the “trauma protocol” allows providers to systematically assess and quickly identify potentially life-threatening injuries, while simultaneously initiating resuscitation. The trauma protocol is composed of primary, secondary, and tertiary surveys, performed in that order.

The goal is to first identify life-threatening injuries and stabilize the patient, which is best accomplished by performing a careful primary survey. This examination involves 5 components: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure. The primary survey must be completed in sequential order, and the patient should receive stabilizing measures at each step, if necessary (e.g., if the patient arrives obtunded an airway should be secured before moving on to breathing assessment), before moving on to the next step.

Option Analysis

✅ Remove all clothing from the patient:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform an E-FAST examination:
Incorrect: An E-FAST examination (focused assessment sonography for trauma) can be part of the secondary survey. This patient has not yet received a comprehensive primary survey as he has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Roll the patient and examine the back:
Incorrect: Examining the back for injuries (step-offs, deformities, rectal tone) is not performed until the primary survey is complete. This patient has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Order Pelvic x-ray:
Incorrect: A pelvic x-ray is not indicated until after the patient has received a complete primary survey. This patient has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Administer one unit of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient does not exhibit findings of significant bleeding or hemodynamic instability on the primary survey thus far. Administration of packed red blood cells is not clinically indicated. And the patient should have proper exposure first.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Upon arrival, the patient appears anxious but speaks in full, clear sentences. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 150/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. There are bilateral breath sounds and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15 and is freely moving all extremities. Pupils are 2-3 mm, equal round, and reactive bilaterally. The patient is exposed, and warm blankets are applied.  IV access is established. The secondary survey reveals four gunshot wounds: one entry wound lateral to the umbilicus on the left, one entry wound inferior to the left clavicle, and corresponding exit wounds over the left flank and medial scapula on the left. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST exam
Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of penetrating trauma and is found to have evidence of two gunshot wounds. Primary survey is completed. as part of the secondary survey. Chest x-ray, pelvis x-ray, and FAST exam should be performed next.

To assess for retained bullet fragments, pneumothorax, and free fluid before proceeding to CT imaging. The presence of any of these findings may change management (e.g., chest tube placement, pericardiocentesis, expeditious transport to the operating room).

The secondary survey should include a detailed history, a thorough but efficient physical examination, and targeted diagnostic tests. Typically blood work will include type and screen, complete blood count (CBC), and complete metabolic profile (CMP). Additional tests can include a coagulation profile, EtOH level, pregnancy test in biologically female patients, and urine toxicology screen. Next, patients should have an ultrasound examination called the FAST exam to assess for free fluid in the pericardium, hepatorenal space on the right, splenorenal space on the left, and pelvis. Patients should also have a chest x-ray and/or pelvis x-ray performed depending on the mechanism of injury. Finally, patients should have CT imaging performed based on the mechanism of injury and injury pattern

Option Analysis

✅ Chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST exam:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis should be performed; however, this patient should first undergo immediate evaluation with a chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST examination to rule out pneumothorax, hemothorax, or free intraperitoneal fluid which would require urgent interventions (e.g., chest tube placement, pericardiocentesis) before proceeding to CT.  
❌ Diagnostic peritoneal lavage:
Incorrect: A diagnostic peritoneal lavage is an uncommonly performed procedure used to assess for intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is not indicated as part of a standard trauma workup.  
❌ EKG and troponin:
Incorrect: An electrocardiogram should be obtained for all trauma patients presenting with blunt cardiac injury. This patient has gunshot wounds and therefore Chest x-ray, pelvis x-ray, and FAST exam should be performed next.
❌ Bedside thoracotomy:
Incorrect: A bedside thoracotomy is reserved for patients with penetrating cardiac trauma, cardiac tamponade on FAST, or pulseless individuals who received CPR within 15 minutes of traumatic thoracic injury. This patient does not indicate this highly invasive procedure.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parent after she felt pulsations on the infant’s head.  The infant was born to a 24-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He has been breastfeeding well. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight and 60th percentile for head circumference. The patient cries when picked up by the physician but is easily consoled by the mother. Moro and grasp reflexes are present. Examination of the head shows soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle. Firm stroking of the soles of the feet causes the big toes to turn up. Which of the following is the best next step?

choices.text: Admit to the infant to the hospital
Alert the department of human services
Refer the patient to a neurosurgeon

questions.solution:
This infant is developing typically, and no intervention is indicated at this time. A soft pulsation may be palpable at the anterior fontanelle.  

There are two fontanelles (the space between the bones of an infant's skull where the sutures intersect) that are covered by tough membranes that protect the underlying soft tissues and brain. The fontanelles include: 
  •  The anterior fontanelle (diamond shaped) is bounded by the two frontal and two parietal bones. Thus it is located at the junction of the sagittal, coronal, and frontal (metopic) sutures, the future site of bregma. It remains soft until about 18 months to 2 years of age. A soft pulsation may be palpable at the anterior fontanelle. 
  •  The posterior fontanelle (triangular shaped) is bounded by the two parietal bones and the occipital bone. It is located at the junction of the lambdoid and sagittal sutures, the future site of lambda. The posterior fontanelle usually closes first, before the anterior fontanelle, during the first several months of an infant's life. 
A sunken anterior fontanelle is primarily due to dehydration. Furthermore, a bulging fontanelle may indicate a rise in intracranial pressure, suggesting multiple pathologies: hydrocephalus, hypoxemia, meningitis, trauma, or hemorrhage. 

Option Analysis

❌ Admit to the infant to the hospital:
Incorrect: The infant is developing normally and should be sent home after scheduling the next well visit. 
❌ Alert the department of human services :
Incorrect: Human services should be alerted in cases of suspected child abuse, which may present with a large, heavy head, retinal hemorrhages, and skeletal fractures. The infant is developing normally and should be sent home after scheduling the next well visit. 
❌ Refer the patient to a neurosurgeon:
Incorrect: A referral to neurosurgeon is indicated in abusive head trauma which may present with a disproportionately large head, full fontanelle, papilledema and retinal hemorrhages. Soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle are a normal finding. 
✅ Reassure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Perform a CT head scan:
Incorrect: A CT head scan is indicated in a neonate with suspected head trauma which may present with a disproportionately large head, full fontanelle, papilledema, and retinal hemorrhages. Soft pulsations in the anterior fontanelle are a normal finding.

questions.text: A three-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to gait disturbance. The patient’s parents have noticed that their son has been falling more frequently while running. In addition, they have observed that he appears to have “knock knees.” They deny any significant injury, and the boy has not been complaining of pain. He was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and is up to date on vaccinations. He can name familiar objects, climbs well, and follows instructions. On physical examination he is well-developed, well-nourished, and speaks in 3-4 word sentences. Physical examination is notable for bilateral genu valgum. His knees are nontender and he has full range of motion without pain. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral genu valgum on physical examination. Clinically and radiographically, valgus deformity will present as “knock knees,” whereas varus deformity will present as “bow legs”. Genu valgum can be a normal finding in patients between the ages of 2-5 years. In the majority of toddlers with physiologic genu valgum, the condition will resolve with age as the long bones of the legs continue to ossify. While genu valgum may be a standard variant in toddlers, it can also represent a pathologic disturbance in the development of long bones.

Measurement of the Q-angle can be used to assess the alignment of the knee joint This angle is found by measuring the angle formed between the quadriceps muscles and the patella tendon. The normal Q angle falls between 12 and 20 degrees when the knee is extended, with males normally falling at the low end of this range and females in the high end.

Large Q-angles outside of the normal range are associated with varus deformities that can be caused by underlying nutritional deficiencies, skeletal dysplasias, growth disorders, or persistence of severe physiologic genu varus after the age of 2 years. Small Q-angles outside of the normal range are indicative of valgus deformity, which may be physiologic in toddlers, or the result of rickets or an underlying skeletal dysplasia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Physiologic genu valgum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cozen fracture:
Incorrect: Cozen fractures are fractures of the proximal tibial metaphysis that can occur in children. They  typically present after an injury with pain of the affected knee.
